Having regard to what had been put before me by Mr McDougall I had to consider the matters raised in Chapter 2 Division 1 of the Evidence Act 1995. I ruled that Mr McDougall was compellable. However, I then drew the attention of Mr McDougall and counsel and the plaintiff to the provisions of s 41 of the Evidence Act which gives me power to disallow questions which were unduly annoying, harassing, intimidating, offensive, oppressive or repetitive. I also can take into account under s 41 any mental, intellectual or physical disability which the witness may be subject to.90 After I gave that judgment the transcript records Mr McDougall as saying this: 
     
      
      “Your Honour, with all due respect I appreciate your considerations here today, but I ain’t giving evidence, in fact I’m going out the door right now. I refuse to hurt myself because of a grub like that and grubs like these two.” 
      
    91 When McDougall said “a grub like that” he gestured towards the plaintiff. When he said “grubs like these two” he gestured at senior counsel for the plaintiff and senior counsel for the defendant. He promptly left the Court.92 Eventually, an application was made by the plaintiff for me to issue a warrant for Mr McDougall’s arrest and for him to show cause why he should not be prosecuted for contempt. I refused those applications. It was clear that Mr McDougall was not the plaintiff’s witness and the only person who is entitled to insist on the enforcement of the subpoena was the defendant who had served the subpoena upon the witness and who wished to call him.93 In my view, the Court was not held in contempt by Mr McDougall, albeit that counsel were insulted, as was the plaintiff. I allowed time for the defendant to obtain instructions. The ruling I made on the application by the plaintiff concerning Mr McDougall was made on 8 August 2006 and has been transcribed.94 On 14 August 2006 the defendant made an application for admission of documents made by McDougall in the process of his investigation of an approach that had been made to him by the plaintiff to be admitted into evidence under either s 63 or s 64 of the Evidence Act. I considered that application and ruled that the documents were admissible under s 64(2) of the Evidence Act, noting the consent of the defendant to the tender of the transcripts of evidence given by McDougall in the criminal proceedings if the plaintiff wished to do so. All such documents have been put into evidence. I do not wish, at this stage, to rehearse all the matters I considered in my ruling on 14 August 2006. I shall merely seek to summarise it so that anyone reading these reasons for judgment when they have been transcribed knows what occurred. 95 McDougall himself made applications for sick leave and hurt on duty benefits because of his involvement in the investigation of the plaintiff and his giving evidence in the prosecution of the plaintiff. Eventually he was medically discharged for inter alia a psychiatric condition which was in part, at least, referable to the trauma which he says he experienced in investigating the plaintiff and in giving evidence in the prosecution. It also emerged that Mr McDougall himself had his own problems with stress and in much of the period in later 1990 with which I am concerned he was absent from duty on sick report and was drinking excessive amounts of alcohol. McDougall himself was cross-examined about that in the criminal proceedings. In re-examination McDougall gave this evidence: 
     
      
      “Q. You were also asked a number of questions concerning your absences from work on sick report between 2 November and sometime in December, do you remember that? 
       
      A. Yes. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. What was your reason for going on sick report? 
       
      A. A decision was made by the superintendent who was the officer in charge of the Illawarra region, that I stay on sick report and concentrate solely on this matter and not be tired up with other everyday duties. 
       
       
      Q. Were you sick during that period? 
       
      A. No, I wasn’t sick. I had been recalled to duty on a number of occasions and was being paid overtime, so I wasn’t sick.” 
      
    96 Mr Somosi was granted leave to further cross-examine McDougall. In that further cross-examination McDougall admitted to answering a number of questions on this very issue at the committal proceedings. At that time McDougall had referred to stress that was brought on him by the inquiry into the plaintiff’s activities and also stress that was being applied to him by the Police Service to engage in the investigation of the plaintiff. Mr McDougall also confirmed evidence he had given at committal about seeing a psychologist, Mr Glancey, during the period that he was on sick report. He was then asked to explain what he meant, when he said that he was not sick in re-examination. This evidence was given: 
     
      
      “Q. You weren’t sick? 
       
      A. Stress is not something you lay on your back kicking your legs or wear your wife’s clothes around the house. It is something in the back of your mind which sometimes effects you more than others. Obviously I was suffering from stress but through Mr Glancey and the relaxation tapes I was in control of it.  
      
     
     
      
      Q. You weren’t sick? 
       
      A. I was on sick report and at times I was sick, I admit that, but stress is a thing that is easily controlled.” 
      
    97 McDougall was then asked about claiming Workcover benefits. It would appear that Mr Somosi was unaware of the provisions of the Police Regulation (Superannuation) Act 1906 and the hurt on duty scheme. However, Mr McDougall admitted to filling in the appropriate forms to claim benefits in respect of his absences from work. In other words, it was offered essentially by Mr McDougall that he was not really sick when he was saying that he was. However, I maintain the reasons I gave on the defendant’s application for the admission of McDougall’s documents under the Evidence Act. McDougall was sick. He was obtaining treatment. He was drinking excessive amounts of alcohol and at times his workmates said that he was irrational.98 The end result is, that Mr McDougall has not given evidence before me and I have not been able to form any opinion of his evidence based on his character or demeanour. Furthermore, there are a number of inconsistencies, if not glaring inconsistencies in his evidence which must cast doubt on his reliability as a witness.99 The weight which I can give to Mr McDougall’s evidence must be attenuated by the fact that he bluntly refused to give evidence before me and did not give evidence. He perceived that it would cause him a further outbreak of illness. He had a recurrent major depressive illness, and that might well have been the case. However, whether it were the case could only be ascertained if he tried to give evidence, which he did not wish to do. The weight to be given to his evidence must be further attenuated by his trying to establish in re-examination the fact that he was not sick when I have found him to have been sick.100 The only judicial officer to have seen and heard Mr McDougall giving evidence and to have published reasons about Mr McDougall’s evidence is the learned magistrate Mr Heaghney. The appeal on the costs order to his Honour Judge Johnston was a re-hearing on paper. The credibility of McDougall at the trial was a matter for the jury to determine and juries do not give reasons. Equally, there may have been some, perhaps, pertinent remarks about that issue by the learned trial judge, Judge Gibson, but his summing up to the jury has not been put before me.101 In considering McDougall’s evidence, I must be guided to a large extent by the observations of Mr Heaghney. For example, on page 4 of his reasons Mr Heaghney said this: 
     
      
      “A careful perusal of the transcripts of the recorded conversations and a careful listening to the recordings themselves, together with a consideration of certain other matters have led me to conclude that the version of the September meeting given by Detective Senior Constable McDougall is scarcely believable.” 
      
    102 On page 8 of his reasons for judgment the learned magistrate said this: 
     
      
      “I have already said something in one context about the conversation at the Burwood RSL of 22 November 1990 in a more general vein the defendant McDougall’s evidence that the versions of these conversations which he has given in his evidence are pretty much word for word is plainly ridiculous especially in respect of this conversation which on his own evidence was a long one. Because these unrecorded conversations as opposed [deposed] to by Senior Constable McDougall do not sit well with the recorded conversations and because the omission from them of material to be found in a number of police information and surveillance reports they must be regarded in my view as having little reliability.” 
      
    103 The weight I can give to the evidence in documentary form from McDougall must be diminished in light of his refusal to undergo cross-examination before me and must carry little weight or reduced weight because I have not had an opportunity to observe him. 104 Of these two considerations of course the adverse inferences I draw about the reliability of the plaintiff favours the defendant’s case and equally the adverse inferences to be drawn from Mr McDougall’s evidence favours the plaintiff’s case. I must approach all the evidence cautiously and carefully and in the end result apply commonsense.105 I turn now to a detailed consideration of the events of 1990. I first need to describe a few things. The first are two loci. The first is licensed premises at Campbelltown. These licensed premises are opposite the Campbelltown courthouse. There once stood on that site an hotel known as Lack’s Hotel. That building appears to have been demolished and replaced by a new building which houses, amongst other things, a tavern which I understands to have the formal name of the Court Tavern. This was often referred to as the new Court Tavern and sometimes that has been transcribed as the New Court Tavern as if the novelty of the establishment was a part of its name. I suspect that it obtained the moniker “new” because it replaced the original hotel. There are references in the transcripts to both new Court Tavern, New Court Tavern, Lack’s Hotel, and Lack’s and “the Pub”. All those are in general references to what I will merely describe as the Court Tavern or the Tavern. 106 The Tavern was described by McDougall in his evidence at trial as being a “policemen’s meeting place”. The Tavern is the place at which Mr Holovinsky worked as a barman on Sunday afternoons since 1985 and 1986. When the plaintiff was released on bail he was stood down from duty but paid his basic salary of office. In order to cover legal costs he needed other employment and as I understand it took full time employment at the Tavern. The Tavern is, as I said, opposite the Campbelltown courthouse. One needs only walk across a public street. I am prepared to take judicial notice of the fact that Campbelltown police station is one block from Campbelltown courthouse, having sat regularly at Campbelltown courthouse in recent times and driven past the police station to get to the courthouse.107 The other locus to which I need describe is a locality on the South Coast of New South Wales known as Yowrie. Yowrie is nineteen kilometres northwest of Cobargo. Cobargo is a village located on the Princes Highway roughly midway between Narooma and Bega. The Yowrie River runs through the locality of Yowrie into the Wadbilliga River which itself is a tributary of the Tuross River. Most of the road from Cobargo to Yowrie is unsealed. That unsealed road continues in to the Wadbilliga National Park. The Wadbilliga National Park is very close to Yowrie, on its western side. On the coast of New South Wales, about twelve kilometres south of Narooma is a place known as Mystery Bay which is immediately north of Cape Dromedary. Cape Dromedary was named by Captain Cook as well as the nearby Mt Dromedary. Whether it was Captain Cook who named Mystery Bay is a mystery to me. From Mystery Bay to Cobargo is a distance of approximately twenty-seven kilometres. Accordingly, from Mystery Bay to Yowrie is a distance of forty-six kilometres. One datum in this case is that there were cannabis plantations growing in the locality of Yowrie. 108 The evidence before me contains a statement made by Detective Senior Sergeant Robert Charles Anderson of the Drug Enforcement Agency (DEA). That tells me that at 5am on Friday 28 December 1990 Anderson attended a briefing at the Bega police station. Following upon that briefing, Anderson, with other police, went to the Yowrie area. A group of police went to an area near Russells Creek where Anderson saw an area cleared of trees and surrounded by wire in which a large number of cannabis plants were growing. A short time later Anderson, with other detectives, went to an area west of the creek where there was another area cleared of trees. That area was surrounded by netting and contained a large plot of cannabis plants covered by netting and two smaller plots of cannabis plants. At another time, Anderson went with other detectives to a third area which was surrounded by netting and contained a large number of cannabis plants. It appears that all of these plantations were being actively irrigated. As I have already stated the estimated street value of the cannabis was some $8.5 million. When exactly the police received the intelligence as to the whereabouts of the cannabis plants I currently am unaware. A document I have read suggests it was Christmas Day 1990. It matters little. All that need be known is that the crops - and I use that word in the plural advisedly - were discovered in late December 1990.109 One of the co-accused of the plaintiff was Mr Mark Leonard Gravener. Mr Gravener had a farm at Yowrie on which was grown asparagus. I do not know whether the asparagus covered the whole of Mr Gravener’s holding, although the evidence suggests to me that it did not cover the whole of his holding. One would have thought if one knows anything of the history of the South Coast of New South Wales that originally the area was a dairy farming area. How close to Mr Gravener’s holding the plantations were the evidence does not disclose. The evidence certainly does not prove that the plantations were on Mr Gravener’s property. 110 In late August or early September there was a meeting at the Tavern which was attended by the plaintiff, Mr William Alfred Treacy and Mr Rod Moore. I have already adverted to the fact that Mr Treacy and the plaintiff attended Merrylands Primary School and Merrylands High School together. In his evidence before me Mr Treacy pointed out that after leaving school the plaintiff was to join the Police Force and Mr Treacy was to become a criminal. In fact Mr Treacy described himself in his evidence as a criminal. It appears from his criminal record that Mr Treacy turned to crime at a very young age. His first appearance was before the Metropolitan Children’s Court on 22 January 1964 for an offence of discharging a firearm in a public place. The penalty imposed at that time was a fine of five pounds or ten days detention. I am sure that anybody who discharged a firearm in a public place at the current time would be glad to received such a penalty. He appeared in the Parramatta Children’s Court in February and again in January and February of 1964 and was convicted of stealing offences. On 3 March 1964 he appeared in Campbelltown Children’s Court on a charge of malicious injury when he was given a good behaviour bond. Within two months he was before the Parramatta Children’s Court for offences of stealing and offensive behaviour. In 1965 there were charges of stealing, larceny, offensive behaviour, driving whilst unlicensed and driving negligently and of breaking, entering and stealing, and finally of culpable driving for which he received a sentence of three years hard labour. The first full time custodial offence had been imposed by the Glebe Local Court on 17 March 1969. That was for four months. Sentences of six months hard labour and fifteen months hard labour had been imposed at the Parramatta Quarter Sessions on 23 June 1965. 111 Treacy appeared before Parramatta Quarter Sessions on 19 June 1968 and was sentenced to three years penal servitude on each of two counts of breaking, entering and stealing. There were two other counts of breaking, entering and stealing for which additional cumulative periods of imprisonment were imposed. Apparently, at some stage, Treacy escaped from gaol and committed more offences. On 7 November 1968 the Parramatta Quarter Sessions imposed sentences of imprisonment for attempting to escape from lawful custody, malicious damage to property, breaking, entering and stealing, larceny and escaping from lawful custody. Those sentences appear to have kept Treacy out of mischief until he appeared in the Sydney District Court on 23 August 1973 and was sentenced to eight years penal servitude for robbery under arms. A three year non-parole period was fixed, however in 1974 he was convicted on further offences of forgery and uttering. Perhaps they occurred whilst he was in gaol. Treacy would have been released from imprisonment in 1976. Between that time and 1987 Treacy’s offences were merely in relation to traffic matters. 112 On 2 July 1987 he was extradited to appear in the Southport Magistrate’s Court on 3 July 1987. For whatever he was charged when he was in Queensland he was found not guilty. On 27 February 1990 Treacy was charged with possessing a prohibited article and possessing an unlicensed pistol. For those offences he was committed for trial in the Sydney West District Court. On 27 February 1990 he was convicted at Campbelltown of assault and of being an unlicensed driver. The fine imposed for the assault was $400 so it could not have been a major offence. However, on 13 July 1999 he was committed for sentence to the South West District Court on a charge of assault occasioning actual bodily harm. For at least one of the offences for which he was committed for trial or sentence in early 1990 Treacy appeared for sentence before this Court at Campbelltown in December 1990 and that will be pointed out during the examination events in that month. 113 Since being discharged by the jury in November 1995 Treacy has been convicted of a further offence. That offence was of conspiring to manufacture amphetamines and was recorded in 1998. Treacy was given a non-parole period of four years and two months and a head sentence of five years and six months. It is understandable why Mr Treacy referred to himself as a criminal.114 Since leaving school, the inference to be drawn from the evidence is that Treacy and the plaintiff had met only irregularly and accidentally. There is references to them meeting each at the golf club or at the pub, or passing each other in the street, or at the shops. They lived in the same area. At relevant times Mr Holovinsky was living at St Andrews and Mr Treacy was living at Ruse. Both of those are suburbs in the Campbelltown area as I understand it. 115 The best that counsel have been able to do to establish when the meeting occurred, which I am currently discussing, was some time in early September 1990, perhaps between 7 and 10 September 1990. Both the plaintiff and Treacy have given evidence to me about this matter and the evidence at trial of Mr Rod Moore about this meeting has also been put before me. There appears to be no dispute what was discussed. Mr Treacy relayed the fact that he had a friend down the South Coast near Cobargo who had a farm. That friend was clearly Gravener, although his name was never mentioned. Treacy told the plaintiff that his friend had seen Henry Charles Landini and some of his mates in the bushland at the back of his property and that his mate and Treacy believed that Landini and his friends were involved in growing a marijuana crop. 116 The plaintiff gave this evidence: 
     
      
      “Q. Did Billy Treacy say anything about what he wanted you to do in terms of dealing with this information? 
       
      A. Well, it was only an inference that he wanted something done about Landini. He also told me that day that there’s no point going to the DEA because the fellow who told him about it when he put Landini in or told the DEA about Landini on the last occasion, his place was turned over and he didn’t trust the DEA. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. Were you told anything about [where] Landini lived? 
       
      A. Yes, he lived down at Mystery Bay somewhere. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. Where was Mystery Bay according to your understanding? 
       
      A. Down the South Coast.” 
      
    117 It appears to have been conveyed at the meeting that Gravener had previously had a dealing with Landini and had confronted him and was scared of him. Gravener had made a complaint to the local police which ended up in the State Drug Crime Commission causing there to be a raid on Gravener’s property, being the execution of a search warrant. Whether it was actually discussed or merely inferred is difficult to know, but it seems that Gravener was afraid of making a further complaint to the local police about Landini. Henry Charles Landini could, on the evidence presented to me, be described as a major criminal. He was known to be a murderer, an extortionist, a drug dealer and a person known to effect what are called “rip-offs”, meaning stealing other persons’ illegal drugs.118 The evidence of Moore confirms that Treacy had a mate at Cobargo and that that mate was terrified of Landini; that Landini had been seen at the back of his property there over a period of two years; that the mate and Treacy suspected that Landini was growing cannabis there; that Landini had in the past tied up and robbed a man who had a nursery at Bega; that the mate at Cobargo was in fear of Landini and was frightened for his family; that the mate at Cobargo had gone to the police; that the police had come out and raided the mate’s place and nothing had happened to Landini; and that Landini lived in Mystery Bay.119 In his evidence, Mr Treacy said this: 
     
      
      “Q. In about august 1990 did Gravener ask you to do something? 
       
      A. He asked me if I could do anything about the situation, that he’s frightened that Danny Landini might come to his house, or he might be doing something that would get him into trouble. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. What did you do? 
       
      A. I spoke to Fred Holovinsky about it.” 
      
    Further on in his evidence in chief, Mr Treacy told me that he told the plaintiff that Landini was living in Mystery Bay and that there would be a situation where Landini would travel down to the Cobargo area. In cross-examination Treacy said that Gravener wanted Treacy to get Landini to “drop off”, that is, to stay away from Gravener’s property. 120 Treacy had given evidence at trial that perhaps Landini could be followed and that would resolve the situation in so much as Landini would know that he was being followed. He agreed that he thought that Landini was being protected by the local police. He said that he thought that Landini would care if he was being followed by the State Drug Crime Commission, by the Federal Police, by the DEA or by lots of people. He went on to say this: 
     
      
      “Q. What made you believe that Landini would care if he suspected he was under police surveillance? 
       
      A. I think Landini - living in a country town and having country police, is a lot different from being followed by police from Sydney. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. So you believe that Landini would be more concerned about police from a major crime squad in Sydney coming down to keep an eye on him rather than by the locals? 
       
      A. That’s correct. That’s correct.” 
      
    121 A few questions later he was asked whether his view when he approached Mr Holovinsky was to organise some sort of surveillance. Mr Treacy’s answer to that question was that Mr Holovinsky, the plaintiff, would pass the information on to the New South Wales Drug Squad.122 It is noted that Mr Treacy stated that whenever he met the plaintiff it would be fair to say that the plaintiff was “half-tanked”. That was the proposition put by learned senior counsel for the defendant with which the witness agreed. I understand Ms Stenmark to have meant by that the plaintiff had drunk a fair amount of alcohol and was at least half intoxicated.123 The inferences to be drawn from the evidence are that Treacy conveyed to Holovinsky intelligence that Landini, who had an alias of “Little Danny” and was sometimes known as Danny Landini, had a cannabis crop near a friend’s property down at Cobargo, that Landini lived at Mystery Bay and could be followed from Mystery Bay to where the crop was at Cobargo and that it would be pointless to ring the local police because the local police were thought to be offering protection to Landini. 124 The concern of Gravener, through Treacy to the plaintiff, was not so much to have Landini arrested, but to warn Landini away from Gravener’s property. If Landini was warned away from Gravener’s property, Gravener would have nothing further to fear. Equally, Landini was such a major criminal that he would probably suspect surveillance and even his suspicion that there was surveillance would be enough to keep him away from Gravener’s property.125 The plaintiff’s case is that when he heard the name of Landini mentioned he was instantly alert, having remembered from his detective’s course that Henry Charles Landini was a major criminal in this State and was always the subject of police inquiries. The plaintiff’s evidence to me is that he thought if he could arrange to have Landini arrested at the cannabis crop site, on the plantation itself, it would be a major coup for the New South Wales Police in having arrested such a notorious criminal and a major coup for the plaintiff himself who could take credit for the arrest of Landini. The plaintiff tells me, and his case is, that he would use the kudos for that arrest to try to have himself re-instated as a detective, which had remained his desire in the Police Force and his preferred career path.126 The mentioning of Landini’s name appears to have had a similar effect on the other person present at the meeting, Rodney George Moore. Mr Moore was, at the time he gave evidence, a self-employed private inquiry agent. He had been in the New South Wales Police Force. He left the New South Wales Police Force in 1986 on medical grounds with the rank of Detective Sergeant. He first met Treacy in this meeting with the plaintiff at the Court Tavern. Mr Moore had known the plaintiff since about 1969 when they had worked together in the Armed Hold-up Squad. 127 Mr Moore’s evidence confirms that when Treacy gave the information about Landini his ears pricked up because when he was in the police, working both the Drug Squad and the Armed Robbery Squad, Landini’s name was one that was constantly in the limelight as being a “heavy criminal”. He had a strong belief of Landini’s reputation as a murderer, an extortionist, a gunman, and being heavily involved in the drug trade, both heroin and Indian hemp. In fact the intelligence gleaned by Moore at this meeting, he was to convey to Detective Sergeant Finch, who was on the DEA. If Landini was arrested from the information he gave to Detective Sergeant Finch, Moore was going to seek a reward. At some later time, probably in November, Mr Moore conveyed to the plaintiff that he had spoken to Detective Sergeant Finch about the information conveyed by Treacy at the meeting, and it is clear that Moore and the plaintiff discussed reward moneys.128 The question is what did the plaintiff do with this intelligence? The plaintiff’s claim is that he passed on this intelligence to Detective Senior Constable McDougall at the Tavern on 21 September 1990. Mr McDougall’s evidence is otherwise. It is otherwise both as to the date of the passing on of the information and as to what the information was. 129 In chief, counsel led from the plaintiff that at the same time that he had this conversation with Treacy and Moore, he had a telephone conversation with McDougall. The inference to be drawn is that it was not at the same time, but some time relatively shortly after the meeting. The plaintiff told me that he was completing records relating to people who had to report to Newtown Police Station as condition of bail. One such person was named Bedek. He had not reported. The plaintiff contacted the police station closest to where Bedek resided and saw that the officer in charge of the matter was McDougall. He left a message for McDougall to contact him in relation to Bedek. The plaintiff said that McDougall phoned him back and that basically the conversation was that McDougall would be “up the pub the following week and he’d see me to have a drink”. He went on to say that he knew McDougall to be working at Warilla Police Station, but the plaintiff told me that he had no idea where Warilla was, meaning that it was down the “south coast” somewhere.130 The plaintiff went on to tell me that on 21 September 1990 he had a conversation with McDougall at the Court Tavern. He confirmed that he had seen McDougall socially on many occasions in the past. In fact the two appeared to have worked together for some short time at Campbelltown. The plaintiff described McDougall as a “big drinker”. That statement may well be self-serving. He also, when asked about Mr McDougall’s behaviour, said this: 
     
      
      “Well, they called him The Crowd. He was the most garrulous big-noter, loud fellow.” 
      
    Again, I must be careful using such evidence because it may well be the result of ex post facto rationalisation.131 The plaintiff went on to tell me this: 
     
      
      “Q. During the time that you were having the conversations with him, what was your state of intoxication and his apparent state of intoxication? 
       
      A. We both would have been well affected. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. Can you tell us what happened in that conversation on 21 September 1990 as best you can, what you said to him? 
       
      A. I said to him that I’ve got a good mate who’s given me some information about Landini, that arsehole Landini, he’s been seen at the back of the bush down behind these blokes’ place and they reckon he’s involved in a crop. I told him that the information was pretty right because it came from a good bloke that I’d known for a long while. I told him to do his homework and it’d be a good pinch. I wrote down on a coaster the name of Henry Charles Landini alias Little Danny and gave it to him.” 
      
    He confirmed that by the words “a good pinch” he meant an arrest and that there would be no better arrest than that of Landini.132 The plaintiff told me that his purpose in passing on that information was to have Landini arrested. He was asked what advantage did he see for himself in giving this information to McDougall and he said this: 
     
      
      “The whole area was governed by promotion by merit and having Landini arrested, me receiving the kudos for it, of being involved in his arrest, I would have hoped it might have given me a better chance of getting back to plain clothes.” 
      
    The plaintiff was then asked why he did not go directly to the DEA and why he gave it to a detective from the South Coast, Wollongong region and the plaintiff said this: 
     
      
      “Well, the last time the DEA were involved they got - this fellow that passed the information on, he was turned over and I thought that if I gave it to McDougall, who I knew to be on the South Coast, he could run the brief from there.” 
      
    In substance, what the plaintiff says he was seeking to do was to give this information to McDougall so that McDougall could do the work necessary to lead to the arrest of Landini. 133 One thing that becomes clear at this hearing is that the plaintiff has the most woeful knowledge of the geography of this State. The only idea that the plaintiff had of where Warilla was, where McDougall was serving, or where Mystery Bay was, or where Cobargo was, and indeed of where Eden was, was that they were all “down the South Coast”. In fact one could be forgiven for thinking that “the South Coast” was yet another suburb of Sydney. I have been perplexed by this lack of geographic knowledge of the State. Is it true or is it feigned? I believe it to be true. In other occasions the plaintiff had no idea where Mystery Bay was and thought it was at Eden. Mystery Bay is a long way from Eden. The plaintiff’s geographical ignorance is a reality, I am afraid, rather than a feigned concoction. The only way in effect that McDougall could do anything with the intelligence was to pass it on to the DEA.134 The version of what happened at this meeting of McDougall and the plaintiff given by McDougall is very different. McDougall says it occurred not on the twenty-first, but on 28 September 1990. The first record that McDougall made of the meeting that he says occurred on 28 September 1990 is recorded in his duty book. Detectives keep duty books, uniformed policemen do not. Both detectives and uniformed policemen have police notebooks which can be used by detectives as well, as they often are by uniformed police. These duty books are not small documents, they are cumbersome and are usually kept at the detective’s office or police station. 135 The first question for me to determine is when the entry for 28 September 1990 was made. It appears to me to be more probable than not that it was made on Thursday 4 October 1990. On that day the duty book records that McDougall was on duty at 8am at Warilla and attended the Local Court at Wollongong concerning Bedek and then he went off duty at 4.30pm. The inference to be drawn is that he would have attended Wollongong Local Court for a sittings commencing at 10. If he went on duty at 8am at Warilla he clearly went to the police station when he could have started the entry or made the entry. The entry over the preceding pages is that which starts on 28 September 1990. It shows that date as being a Friday and being a day when McDougall was on annual leave but was recalled to duty. As I read the entry it is this: 
     
      
      “On duty 8am Warilla out to Liverpool District Court re Stancou Aga so employed to 1pm meal 1.30pm further duty re same to 4.30pm off duty. 
      
     
     
      
      6pm the New Court Tavern Campbelltown. Speak to Sergeant Fred Holovinsky re Bedek inquiry. Holovinsky requested that I follow him to toilet for discussion. Followed to men’s toilet. Holovinsky informs me that he is involved in a plantation on the South Coast with Bill Treacy and Landini. ‘Nothing wrong with a bit of green. Wouldn’t mind if you kept an ear out - if you hear anything give us a call and it will be worth quid to you.’ ‘You’ll never find a plantation - it’s a sure thing.’ 
      
     
     
      
      Upon returning home contacted Detective Bridge at drug squad and informed. 
      
     
     
      
      29/9/90 contact and inform Detective Sergeant Woods inform of same. Tried to contact Plantation Unit re same. Unsuccessful. 
      
     
     
      
      Contact DEA. Obtain Detective Sergeant Beaumont’s number. Call pager. 4.45pm speak to Beaumont. 
      
     
     
      
      Sunday 30 September 90. Speak to Detective Sergeant Beaumont of Plantation Unit at Lake South.” 
      
    Lake South is the southern entrance to Lake Illawarra at Windang. 136 Exhibit 44 is a report of Detective Sergeant Peter J Woods of the Warilla Police Station. I infer that McDougall was working under Detective Sergeant Woods. Detective Sergeant Woods confirms that on Saturday 29 September 1990 he received a telephone call at his home from Detective Senior Constable McDougall attached to Warilla Police Station. He confirmed that he received a further telephone call from McDougall later on the same day and was told by McDougall that Detective Senior Sergeant Beaumont of the Plantation Unit was coming down to see him on the following day, the Sunday. That Senior Sergeant Beaumont of the Plantation Unit attended upon McDougall on the Sunday morning at Lake South is not disputed.137 Eventually McDougall was directed to prepare a written report of what had occurred with the plaintiff. The report confirms that McDougall approached the plaintiff to talk about Bedek. It confirms that after a short period engaged in that conversation the plaintiff asked McDougall to follow him into the toilet as he had a proposition that he wanted to put to him. The statement continues thus: 
     
      
      “Sergeant Holovinsky went to the male toilet situated between the two bars of the hotel in a hallway. I followed him in a short time later. When I entered the toilet I saw Sergeant Holovinsky check the cubicles by pushing open the doors.  
      
     
     
      
      Sergeant Holovinsky said ‘Are you interested in earning a quid?’ I said ‘Depends on what it is. What do you mean?’ He said ‘You’re on the South Coast aren’t you?’ I said ‘Yes.’ He said ‘I’ve got two mates down there growing a bit of green, there is nothing wrong with a bit of green, it is not that other shit, smack. Anyway, they got a plantation down there and we might want a hand with it.’ I said ‘What sort of hand?’ He said ‘Just keep an ear out, if you hear anything you know anybody asking questions, just give us a call. It’s worth a quid to you.’ I said ‘Where is the plantation?’ He said ‘You’d never find it, it’s well hidden, it’s safe, a sure thing. They’re good blokes too, you know Billy Treacy don’t you?’ I said ‘He’s from Bankstown isn’t he?’ He said ‘You know him, him and Landini?’ He said ‘Bobby, it’s a sure thing, just keep your ears open and let us know, there’s a grand in it for you. It’s only a bit of green otherwise I wouldn’t be involved, not if it was that other shit. You know where I am, just give me a call.’ Sergeant Holovinsky then walked from the toilet. I waited a few moments and then walked from the toilet to an adjoining bar. I got a coaster and pen and wrote down the names Billy Treacy and Landini. I then returned to the bar where I was drinking. I saw that Sergeant Holovinsky was standing at the bar drinking with some civilians. I returned to the bar and bought a drink and took up a conversation with some other people at the hotel. A short time later I left and returned to my home.” 
      
    The statement goes on to record that when he reached his home he contacted Warilla VKG and requested they activate a pager for the Wollongong Drug Squad. 138 A short time later McDougall received a telephone call from Detective Senior Constable Bridge. McDougall stated that he informed Detective Bridge of his conversation with Sergeant Holovinsky and requested that he make a note of it for future reference.139 An interesting thing in this case is that despite the volumes of paper that have been put before me there is no statement from Senior Constable Bridge nor is there any note put before me that he may have made on the evening of 28 September 1990. However, equally there was no challenge to McDougall at any time that he did make that phone call to Warilla VKG. 140 The first enquiry that I must make is when did the meeting occur? The only thing I can conclude on the evidence is it occurred on 28 September 1994. I know why McDougall was at the District Court at Campbelltown. Even if the Police Force cannot keep good records, the courts do at least a better job and the listing of the matter at the Campbelltown District Court on 28 September 1990 could easily be proved or disproved. No attempt was made to disprove it. It is common ground that McDougall went to the hotel after finishing at court. If court rose at four McDougall could have been in the tavern by 4.05. He records the approach to him by Mr Holovinsky in his duty book as being at 6pm. One can infer therefore that McDougall had been in the hotel taking beer for approximately two hours before he had the conversation with the plaintiff. I do not know for how long the plaintiff may have been at the pub on that day. It is accepted by the plaintiff that he was well affected by alcohol and, again, to use a term much used by counsel, “half tanked”. Of course the plaintiff makes the same allegation about McDougall, but that may be self-serving. However, it is clear that after the conversation and probably having a beer with the plaintiff, McDougall had another beer before he drove himself home. One can accept that there was a period of at least two and a half hours of drinking by McDougall which could have affected his memory of things.141 However, the drive from the Court Tavern to McDougall’s home at Warilla required a journey of 120 kilometres which would take at least an hour and a half. I do not know if at that time or even currently that police officers believe themselves to be protected from drink driving random breath tests. I cannot make any finding as to the exact extent of McDougall’s sobriety, however, the plaintiff admits that he was “half tanked”. 142 However, I am only really concentrating at this time as to when the conversation occurred. McDougall goes home, makes a call that evening, the non-existence of which call could be proved, and that has not been done. It is clear the next morning he contacts both his immediate superior, Detective Sergeant Woods, who advises him to phone the Plantation Unit of the DEA, which McDougall does, and McDougall has an interview with Beaumont of the DEA on the following day, the Sunday.143 All those documents speak of the event occurring on 28 September. How, I ask myself, could Mr Holovinsky deny that it occurred then and know it occurred on the twenty-first when he has no records whatever? He would have been first asked to think about when the conversation might have occurred some time after his arrest. No doubt, after his arrest and imprisonment he would have spent a long time thinking about what had happened to him and how things may have come about. Equally, as I have sought to make out, the plaintiff spent a lot of time labouring under the influence of alcohol. The only finding I can make is that the meeting occurred on 28 September 1990. Why would the plaintiff bother to dispute that? Nothing really much turns on it. 144 However, the plaintiff seeks here, and also sought at trial, to establish a time delay to enable firstly a gap in time which would further reduce McDougall’s memory and allow a period of time on which he might have reflected over the information that had been supplied to him. In other words, deliberately disputing the time involved and seeking to give a period of time before McDougall raises his report, gave the plaintiff an opportunity to attack McDougall.145 The essential question for me is which of the two versions of this conversation is the correct one or is there some other plausible explanation of what occurred? The first thing to note is that this conversation followed upon the conversation that there had been had earlier in the month at the Court Tavern between Treacy, the plaintiff and Moore. If one leaves aside at the moment the plaintiff’s recall of that conversation as being self-interested and the recall of that conversation by Treacy as being tainted because of his status as a criminal, one is still left with the version of that conversation given by Mr Moore who is at least one person whose credit has not been impugned in this case.146 I therefore can accept the conversation which I will broadly outline that occurred between the plaintiff, Treacy and Moore in early September 1990. The meeting between the plaintiff and McDougall concerned the same matter. The complexion put on it by McDougall is very different to the complexion of the conversation that had earlier been had by Treacy, Moore and the plaintiff. That, in my view, attenuates the weight to be given to McDougall’s version.147 Common to both the versions of the plaintiff and McDougall are the mention of the name Landini, the mention of the name Treacy, the mention of “a cannabis crop”, the mention of the South Coast and the mention of a benefit to McDougall. According to McDougall the benefit is “a quid”. According to Holovinsky the benefit is a “good pinch”. Holovinsky also says that there was mention of the name Cobargo. That was the position he adopted throughout his evidence both at committal and trial. It was clearly a name that was mentioned by Treacy and heard by Moore. It is to be recalled that the plaintiff was “half tanked” and that McDougall had been drinking beer for about two hours. It is quite plausible that the plaintiff may have said something that McDougall misinterpreted. Equally it is plausible that because of Holovinsky’s alcohol intake he expressed himself in a way that could easily have been misinterpreted by McDougall. 148 I accept that the word “quid” was used by the plaintiff, but the fact that McDougall might make a quid for himself might be explicable by his earning a reward for the arrest. If the word quid was used, and I believe it was used, because that is the important word recorded by McDougall in his duty book, then one linking Landini, Treacy, the cannabis crop and the South Coast and a quid could easily be mixed up by McDougall or have been communicated ineptly by the plaintiff to McDougall who took it to mean something other than what the plaintiff meant.149 I am prepared to accept that the plaintiff did mention the name Cobargo. There was no reason why he should not because it was openly discussed by Treacy in the presence of Moore. It may well be that McDougall forgot about the mention of Cobargo.150 Assuming that the elements of the conversation are Landini, Treacy, cannabis crop, South Coast and a quid, does the version put forward by McDougall add up? Perhaps to jump ahead of myself I should point out this. It will become increasingly clear as I discuss further developments that there was absolutely no relationship between Landini and Treacy. They were not known criminal associates. Treacy disliked Landini. In fact it was mentioned at one stage that Treacy detested Landini. No link whatever has ever been established between Treacy and Landini. In fact it became clear that the plaintiff wanted only essentially one thing to occur to Landini, that he be arrested. Mr McDougall acknowledged this repeatedly when giving evidence. 151 Once one takes out of the elements Landini and Treacy being mates of the plaintiff, it can quickly be seen that the version of events given by McDougall falls apart. It also ought to have become clear to the investigating police that once Landini and Treacy were not mates of each other, and in particular that Landini was not a mate of Mr Holovinsky, that there was a serious and fundamental flaw in the investigation mounted by the police against the plaintiff and a serious error in the information relayed by McDougall to his superiors in the Police Force.152 Furthermore, the version of events given by McDougall is inherently improbable. It is inherently improbable for a number of reasons. Firstly, if a notorious criminal, Landini, and a criminal, Treacy, had a marijuana crop down the South Coast which could return them over eight million dollars, one would expect that they would do their best to preserve its integrity and if it was necessary to have an agent in the Police Force, then to choose somebody who was reliable and dependable, albeit corrupt. Somebody who was almost permanently half tanked would hardly be reliable. If the plaintiff had been involved in this enterprise, if there were such an enterprise, then how could his mates who were involved in the enterprise, accept that Holovinsky could keep his mouth shut in his cups? It is implausible. 153 But the implausibility is added to further by these considerations. There is nothing to suggest that Holovinsky knew that McDougall was corruptible or likely to take a bribe or become part of an illegal scheme. The evidence does not disclose any reason to think that McDougall was corruptible. Here is a patent approach by Holovinsky to McDougall without any attempt to feel McDougall out as to whether he might be susceptible to corruption. There is no “sounding out” of McDougall by the plaintiff. If the plaintiff were involved with a cannabis crop on the South Coast which could return millions of dollars in money, one would think that he would be very circumspect in approaching a policeman to try to inveigle that policeman into the criminal enterprise. Why would he approach somebody without trying to sound out the policeman as to whether he were corruptible? 154 The next implausibility is that if the plaintiff were conspiring with Treacy and/or Landini, that he would mention in the first contact the co-conspirators’ names. 155 Another thing which I must bear in mind is the statement in the first paragraph that I’ve quoted from McDougall’s report about the scene of this conversation on his version of it, a conversation in the men’s lavatory. According to McDougall, Holovinsky checked to ensure that no one else was present by checking the cubicles and by pushing open the doors of each cubicle. It was established at trial, one would think incontrovertibly, that there was only one toilet stall, one cubicle, in the lavatory in question and that that toilet cubicle was fitted with a door which had a spring which kept the door permanently opened outward unless somebody entered the stall and sought to lock the door to ensure privacy.156 It may well be that the conversation occurred in the lavatory, but clearly the detail supplied by McDougall in his statement is quite unreliable. 157 One must note that the plaintiff said that he wrote down the name Henry Charles Landini, Little Danny on a coaster and gave it to McDougall. McDougall said that he got the coaster and he wrote on it the names Billy Treacy and Landini. The coaster was clearly one kept by McDougall. In a formal statement that he prepared for use in court, made after the arrest of the plaintiff, McDougall wrote in his statement “I produce that coaster”. It has never been produced. McDougall said, and I am quite prepared to accept that he gave it either to a superior officer, either to Detective Sergeant Krawczyk or Detective Sergeant Beaumont. 158 Of course the plaintiff interprets the loss of the coaster in a nefarious fashion that if it were produced it would show his handwriting on it and the failure to produce it was because to do so would be to the embarrassment to McDougall. That is a possibility, but it would involve grave moral turpitude. The reality of life is that things can easily be explained by the more probable method of it just having gone astray somewhere when somebody failed to realise that it might become quite significant.159 A further implausibility is when the name of Billy Treacy being mentioned that McDougall insert the matter “He’s from Bankstown isn’t he?” Well Treacy was not a Bankstown boy nor was he a Balmain boy, he was a Merrylands boy, who subsequently moved to the Campbelltown area. The plaintiff would have know him as a Merrylands man or a local man and if Treacy and McDougall asserted that he was from Bankstown one would have thought that the plaintiff would have disabused McDougall of that misinformation. However, that does not occur in McDougall’s version of what occurred.160 Another significant matter from my point of view is that in the statement there is mention of “a grand” meaning, I assume, $1,000. However, the specific offer of $1,000 is not contained in McDougall’s duty book. All that is mentioned there is “a quid”. Why would he write in his duty book “a quid” if the offer was in fact $1,000? 161 Merely on the considerations I have raised thus far the version of the conversation offered by the plaintiff appears to be more probable than that offered by McDougall.162 As I discuss, as I shall tomorrow, subsequent events, it becomes even clearer in my view that the proposition put by McDougall in his report of there being a conspiracy involving Landini, Treacy and the plaintiff is just not supportable.STOOD OVER PART HEARD TO FRIDAY 25 AUGUST 2006FRIDAY 25 AUGUST 2006163 Shortly before I rose yesterday at approximately 5pm, I made a finding that the version of the initial conversation between the plaintiff and McDougall that I held occurred on 28 September 1990 was probably more in line with what the plaintiff said than with what McDougall alleged. In making that finding I also bear in mind what I will say about subsequent developments in the interaction between the plaintiff and McDougall. However, there is one further thing that I should add. It requires me to go back a little to discuss the relationship between the plaintiff and Treacy.164 Mr Treacy made it clear that he approached the plaintiff, knowing him to be a Sergeant of Police and a former Detective because of the antecedent relationship between the two of them. Mr Treacy, as I have said, described himself as a criminal and it became clear from his evidence that he would not have volunteered any information to any member of the police force other than the plaintiff because he had an expectation, that might be the best way of describing it, that the plaintiff would respect the information that Treacy provided to the plaintiff and also respect Treacy’s privacy. Mr Treacy made it clear that he did not want his information to be ascribed to him, Mr Treacy; in other words, that he was to remain completely anonymous.165 In the electronically recorded conversations between the plaintiff and McDougall after 28 September 1990 Treacy’s name is never mentioned, the plaintiff referring to Treacy as either “my informant” or “my gig”. It is otherwise in the conversations recorded in notes made by McDougall after the conversations had occurred and for which there is no corroboration.166 The question, which arises, is why the plaintiff mentioned Treacy to McDougall. It is clear that he did because both of them say so. The reason is likely, in my view, to be disinhibition on the part of the plaintiff because of the amount of alcohol that he had consumed.167 The thrust of the plaintiff’s evidence and his case is this: He obtained what he thought to be important criminal intelligence from Treacy. He thought it could be used to effect an arrest of Landini. He thought that purpose of greater moment that merely discovering the cannabis plantation or plantations. 168 His idea was that if Landini were successfully arrested on this plantation he could receive some kudos which would further his career. For that purpose the plaintiff alleges he passed on this intelligence to McDougall in the expectation that McDougall would use the intelligence to build up a brief which could lead to the arresting of Landini at the plantation site and his successful prosecution. The plaintiff maintained that in that way he would get kudos from the arrest because he was the source of intelligence for McDougall. 169 The submission of the defendant is that that plan or course of action was implausible and incredible. Objectively, there is very much to be said for that. However, if one considers the matter, bearing in mind certain attributes of the plaintiff to which I have referred, it can be seen that the matter may have appeared to be less implausible to the plaintiff. 170 The first attribute, of course, is his geographical ignorance. True, it would seem objectively, to be implausible, to impart information to a Detective Senior Constable at Warilla in order to arrest somebody who lived at Mystery Bay and had a drug plantation in the region of Cobargo. The Warilla patrol extended from the entrance to Lake Illawarra to the commencement of Seven Mile Beach which is at Gerroa. There would then be the Nowra patrol and a number of other patrols before one got to Cobargo which is in the Bega patrol. The major sites after Nowra are, of course, Milton, Ulladulla, then Batemans Bay, Moruya and then Narooma. However, as far as the plaintiff was concerned, all these places were on “the South Coast”. 171 The next thing is that one must look at it as Mr Holovinsky was, essentially through amber coloured spectacles, through the bottom of a schooner glass. The plaintiff may well in his cups have not realised how objectively implausible the position was. Equally, since intoxication inhibits the thinking process, he may not have adverted to the fact that the kudos for the arrest of Landini might be claimed and/or assigned to McDougall rather than to him and may not have realised that to effect the arrest McDougall would have to involve the DEA.172 A major hesitation which I have in accepting the thrust of the plaintiff’s position is why he did not turn and give his information to the DEA. It is clear that it was corruption at the local level that was suspected by Gravener, that is that it was the police in the Cobargo/Bega area who were in with Landini. It is also clear that the raid which was carried out on Gravener’s property in the past was carried out by the State Drug Crime Commission, probably using the manpower of the DEA. 173 However, that does not mean that the DEA itself were involved in the corruption that favoured Landini. It depends on what intelligence may have been passed by the local police to State Drug Crime Commission. They could have omitted any reference to Landini and merely mentioned that they suspected that Gravener had a plantation.174 The plaintiff has maintained that it was because of the involvement of the DEA in the first raid on Gravener’s property that caused him not to approach the DEA himself but to approach McDougall.175 I am very sceptical about that explanation but weighing all things together, as I must, it still seems to me that the plaintiff’s version of what happened at the meeting, the first meeting between him and McDougall is more probable than that alleged by McDougall.176 At this stage one must consider what the plaintiff should have done when he was given criminal intelligence by Treacy. Exhibit 38 is the New South Wales Police Informant/Reward Plan published in September 1997. Exhibit 29 is a New South Wales Police Circular dated 9 October 1987 which in itself is a précis of exhibit 38. 177 The preface to the Informant/Reward Plan is this: 
     
      
      “The management of intelligence is crucial to the policing function. The community generally and ‘police informants’ in particular are a major source of intelligence. 
      
     
     
      
      Paradoxically, police involvement with rewards and informants is a high risk area with the potential of attracting a great deal of criticism to the individual member and to the Force as a whole. Consequently, this function warrants the closest supervision. 
      
     
     
      
      This plan formalises policies and procedures in relation to informants and rewards. It protects individual police against unfair attack and ensures that the Force, as a whole, is in a position to meet any criticism in relation to the disbursement of rewards.” 
      
    That preface sounds some notes of caution. 178 The first two paragraphs of the plan ought also be considered. They are these: 
     
      
      “1. The ethical management of police informants is a matter of paramount importance for the effective and efficient operation of the New South Wales Police Force. Likewise, acknowledgement by this Force, for assistance given, is seen as extremely important in the overall management of this organisation.  
      
     
     
      
      2. By the very nature of their duties it is essential for police, particularly those engaged on criminal investigation duties, to cultivate and maintain contact with informants. Many of these persons are either suspected of being actively engaged in crime or, at least, consorting with known, active criminals. Consequently, police contact with informants is fraught with an element of danger in that it provides the basis for suggesting improper relationships and, or, implication by Police in criminal activities.” 
      
    179 The Plan requires that police informants be registered. A police informant is defined as a person who, for monetary or other gain, supplies information on criminal activities to a member of the police force. The Plan is detailed and I shall not quote it in this judgment. Part of it, headed “Annexure A1”, lays out duties devolving from the Plan and one set of duties falls upon “case officers”, the case officer being the policeman who takes the intelligence from the police informant.180 It is common ground that the plaintiff did not register Treacy as a police informant because Treacy did not want to be registered as a police informant. The plaintiff ignored the Informant/Reward Plan essentially because that is what Treacy wanted him to do. 181 The next thing the plaintiff should have done is to have reduced the intelligence communicated to him to writing in the form of a report so that it could be processed onwards. Had the plaintiff done that and even if the only person to whom he passed on the report was McDougall, there would not have been the opportunity of McDougall’s misinterpreting the information being passed on by the plaintiff. The plaintiff ought, having reduced his intelligence to writing, to have passed it on to his immediate superior or to the head of detectives where he served or directly to a State investigative body such as the State Drug Crime Commission or the DEA or, indeed, to Internal Affairs because part of the intelligence conveyed to the plaintiff was a suggestion of corruption at the local level between police and Landini.182 The plaintiff did none of those things. The plaintiff passed on his information to McDougall, probably in the lavatory of a hotel at Campbelltown, when he was, on his own admission, “half tanked”. The procedures in place were in fact there, to a large extent, for the protection of the policeman himself. By ignoring proper police procedure the plaintiff could be seen, at the very least, as contributing to what befell him. By not placing his intelligence in writing, by not registering his informant and by going sideways, not upwards, in the police organisation the plaintiff could expect to fall under suspicion. That is exactly what occurred.183 The defendant went to great pains, and very successfully in my view, to point out what the correct procedures were and how the plaintiff did not follow those procedures and how, to use a neutral word, how entirely “informal” the procedure was that the plaintiff adopted.184 I return to the events after 29 September 1990. As I have said, there is no dispute that McDougall spoke to Detective Sergeant Woods on 29 September 1990 and to Detective Senior Sergeant Beaumont on 30 September 1990. That was a Sunday. Monday 1 October 1990 would have been the Labour Day holiday.185 On Tuesday 2 October 1990 Detective Sergeant Woods spoke to McDougall about his contact with Detective Senior Sergeant Beaumont. On 3 October 1990 Detective Sergeant Woods informed Chief Inspector Brook, the Patrol Commander at Warilla, of McDougall’s allegations.186 On Friday 5 October 1990 reports were made by Detective Sergeant Woods and by McDougall in writing and they were forwarded on by Chief Inspector Brook to the District Commander for the Wollongong District and to the Regional Commander South which, as I understand it, covered the area from the Illawarra to the New South Wales/Victorian border. This intelligence was also forwarded on by the District Commander at Wollongong to Internal Affairs.187 It is clear that McDougall was extremely reluctant to be involved in the investigation and had to be ordered and then cajoled to do so. At the criminal trial much was made of that and the “spin” put on McDougall’s reluctance was his guilty knowledge of his attempt to incriminate the plaintiff by verballing him. However, the reluctance of McDougall can be seen in more human terms by the reluctance of any member of a disciplined organisation to give information against another member of that organisation, especially when the two are known to each other and have worked together. I understand this to be sometimes known as being reluctant to be a “rat in the ranks”. 188 On 12 October 1990 it was necessary for Detective Senior Sergeant Krawczyk of the Drug Enforcement Agency, who essentially took over the investigation of the allegations of McDougall against the plaintiff, to meet with McDougall to encourage him and persuade him to persist in the investigation by being an agent provocateur. McDougall was to pose as a policeman who had agreed to join in the plaintiff’s alleged corrupt enterprise, to play along in the role as a “corrupt cop”.189 The meeting between Krawczyk and McDougall was held at the Group 7 Leagues Club at Kiama. It would appear that the meeting lasted for eight and a half hours, ending at 12.30am. It did involve dinner but the clear inference is that it also involved the drinking of alcohol. One cannot leave the current case without noting that whether it was the plaintiff or those investigating him, many police conferences were held in licensed premises. This was criticised as far as the plaintiff was concerned by the defendant but the defendant’s own witnesses freely admitted to often meeting in licensed premises where a drink might be consumed from time to time.190 The next contact between the plaintiff and McDougall occurred on 26 October 1990. That was a Friday. It happened at 2.14pm, according to McDougall, when the plaintiff was at the Court Tavern. 191 Paragraph 15 of McDougall’s statement of 4 January 1991 sets out the conversation and paragraph 15 mirrors the notes that McDougall said he made after the contact which are exhibit 46. Paragraph 15 is in these terms: 
     
      
      “On 2.14pm that day 1990 I telephoned the defendant at the new Court Tavern. I spoke to a barman and a short time later the defendant came onto the telephone. He said ‘Hello’. I said ‘Yeah. Fred? Bob McDougall.’ He said ‘Gidday, mate’. I said ‘Remember that fishing trip we spoke about?’ He said ‘Yeah’. I said ‘Well, I might come up and have a talk to you about it. I’m on afternoon shift tonight.’ He said ‘Yeah, good idea. Are they running down there or just hanging about?’ I said ‘Yes, running. Listen, I’ll talk to you when I see you.’ He said ‘Yah, we might catch a couple of them’.” 
      
    McDougall was challenged on the basis that the plaintiff had an interest in fishing and that the conversation was about fishing. It may well have been. Equally, as Mr Gross has submitted in the current matter, the conversation and the reference to fish might be a reference to police and Holovinsky wanted to know whether the fish were active or inactive, that is whether something was being done about investigating Landini.192 On 31 October 1990 there was a telephone conversation between the plaintiff and McDougall which was electronically intercepted. It alludes to the fact that the plaintiff and McDougall had not met on 26 October 1990. Apparently McDougall turned up at the Court Tavern but the plaintiff had left. The plaintiff said in the conversation that he was unable to wait any longer as he had to be home “for the kids”. The conversation records that McDougall had managed to leave aside his work partner somewhere and said that he wished to talk to the plaintiff about fishing. It was McDougall who raised the subject of fishing. 193 Arrangements were made to meet at the Court Tavern after lunch on 1 November 1990. The conversation itself does not suggest anything of a criminal or suspicious nature. It was McDougall pressing to make contact with the plaintiff and arrangements being made for a get together at the usual watering hole. Furthermore, the conversation as recorded at page 1262 of exhibit 5 indicates no sense of urgency or priority or purpose that one might associate with somebody who is keen to protect a cannabis plantation worth $8.5 million.194 Mr Holovinsky did not wait around for McDougall to turn up because he had to go home for domestic reasons. Equally, in setting the time for the next meeting, it could not be set at such a time as would interfere with the plaintiff’s playing of golf. Again, if the plaintiff were involved in some criminal activity involving cannabis plantations with the aim of making money, he had a very strange set of priorities. 195 On 1 November 1990, according to McDougall, he arrived at the Court Tavern at 3pm. At about 3.45pm the plaintiff came into the bar area and there was a conversation between them. Paragraph 21 of McDougall’s statement of 4 January 1991 contains his version of the conversation. It is this: 
     
      
      “The defendant said to these other men ‘Excuse me fellows, we need to talk a bit of business.’ I left the table and with the defendant I walked to the servery area of the bistro. The defendant said ‘How’s it going?’ I said ‘Good’. He said ‘Listen, that stuff I was talking to you about the other day is not on. I’ve heard it’s too hot down there.’ I said ‘How do you mean?’ He said ‘I’ve spoken to my mate Treacy and there is six cars around his house. He reckons he is being followed. He called me about 2pm. It’s too hot.’ I said ‘What do you mean it’s too hot? Who’s too hot?’ He said ‘Your blokes were all right.’ He said ‘It’s not my blokes it’s Danny, Danny Landini. Danny is down at a plantation at Eden. Not Henry but Danny. My blokes are okay. Did you know that I went to school with Bill?’ I then spoke with the defendant in relation to other matters. A short time later we went back to the table and joined the other males.” 
      
    196 There is no dispute that the police had arranged observation of Mr Treacy. Mr Treacy, having some expertise as a criminal, was clearly able to observe the fact that he was being observed. I would have little doubt that Treacy would complain to Holovinsky about being observed if his only recent contact with the police was his imparting of the intelligence concerning Landini and the cannabis plantation down the South Coast in early September 1990. No doubt Mr Treacy would be extremely suspicious of the plaintiff in that the plaintiff may have breached his confidence which, indeed, he had by passing on his name to McDougall.197 The rest of the conversation recorded by McDougall makes little sense. There was no suggestion that there was anything happening at Yowrie or Cobargo or anywhere on the South Coast that made things “too hot”.198 After that conversation which would have only taken a few minutes both the plaintiff and McDougall returned to the drinking school. McDougall alleges that there was a further conversation between the pair at 7.14pm. One must consider how much alcohol may have been consumed between 3.45pm, although it may have been 3.35pm and 7.14pm. 199 In cross-examination at page 2476 of exhibit 11 McDougall admitted that the plaintiff was a heavy drinker; was asked how much the plaintiff may have drunk between 3.35pm and 7.14pm, to which McDougall did not have an answer. It was suggested to McDougall that the plaintiff had about twelve schooners of beer. McDougall was not able to answer that question either in that he said he did not know. This was then said: 
     
      
      “Q. Well twelve schooners would not sound excessive for Fred Holovinsky in your observation of him in a four hour period one afternoon, would it? 
       
      A. I don’t think so, no, but twelve schooners is your opinion.  
      
     
     
      
      SOMOSI: My instructions not my opinion.” 
      
    200 Clearly, the instructions given by the plaintiff to his counsel, Mr Somosi, was that during such a period he would have consumed twelve schooners. Those instructions may have been self-serving, the more alcohol the plaintiff had the less likely he would be able to, firstly, follow the conversation, secondly, answer coherently and, thirdly, remember what was said, thereby seeking to exculpate himself. However, the period from 3.35 to 7.14 is a period of three and a half hours and one could easily accept the plaintiff drinking at least seven schooners during that period which, in itself, is a fair amount of alcohol. 201 According to McDougall, the conversation was this: 
     
      
      “About 7.14pm the same evening the defendant said to me ‘Can I steal five minutes?’ I again went with the defendant to the main servery area of the bistro. He said ‘Are you all right or not, tell me’. I said ‘I’m okay’. He said ‘Listen, we want a hand’. I said ‘Well look, there’s lots of action down there. Give me an indication of where it's at. I can’t come back to you every time someone has a look down there in the south. I’d come unstuck real quick.’ He said ‘Look, I don’t know. It’s down there somewhere. I can’t tell you. Listen there’s a big quid in it for you. At least fifteen thousand. Just for keeping me in touch. My share is fifty thousand dollars. That’s how big it is. Mate they don’t even trust me.’ I said ‘Fred, tell me roughly where it is. I can’t come running to you every time I have a whisper. I have to have a rough idea.’ He said ‘I can’t tell you. Mate this is a big one, on top of a mountain. You never find it. They’d never find it.’ I said, ‘As I said, I can’t come here all the time. I work down there. I can’t keep coming up here. It’s too risky today.’ He said ‘Fuck’em’. 
      
     
     
      
      I asked around. I was told I could trust you’. I said ‘Fred, I’m in. I need the dough. Fifteen thousand would pay off my house tomorrow.’ He said ‘Me too’. At the stage another drinker came and spoke to us, interrupting the conversation. The defendant said ‘Keep in touch’.” 
      
    202 The statement of McDougall indicates that he went to a police vehicle parked outside the hotel, made notes of this conversation, then later drove to the Appin Hotel where he had a meeting with Detective Sergeant Krawczyk and Moore. That Detective Sergeant Moore is not to be confused with Mr Rod Moore.203 The first thing to note about these conversations is that the notes were made, say, at about 7.30pm and include notes of the conversation at 3.35pm. They also are notes of the conversation at 7.14pm. McDougall, on his own admission, had by this time been in the hotel for four and a quarter hours. McDougall’s normal drink was a full strength, although he said on occasions he had to drink light beer because of the need to drive from, for example, the Court Tavern at Campbelltown to his home at Kiama, a distance of 120 kilometres.204 In essence, before the learned magistrate and before the jury, McDougall maintained that the notes that he made of these conversations were verbatim or almost verbatim. The learned magistrate could not accept that assertion, nor can I. Anyone who has sat in court for any length of time and listened to evidence being given, in effect a conversation between counsel and witness, knows that it is often difficult to recall what was said ten minutes ago, let alone what was said hours ago. Indeed, if counsel’s question is objected to and an argument follows, counsel often cannot remember the question he or she asked to which the objection was made.205 The only thing I need say at this stage about the first conversation, that is that at 3.35pm, is that the plantation was not at Eden. According to the plaintiff, all he knew was that he was at Cobargo and he had told that to McDougall at the first meeting. If McDougall had forgotten it, then I can only assume that if he had told the plaintiff that the plaintiff would have reminded him that it was at Cobargo.206 There are a large number of implausibilities in the conversation alleged to have occurred at 7.14pm. 207 The first part of it deals with, essentially, McDougall’s agreeing to be part of the scheme he alleged that the plaintiff was involved in. The problem with that is that had already been discussed and agreed according to McDougall’s earlier evidence and conversations. The next part of it is the sudden escalation of the remuneration offered to McDougall by the plaintiff. According to McDougall, the first amount of money offered to him was $1000. This suddenly escalates into $15,000 without anything having occurred in the interim, other than Treacy’s being observed by the police and Treacy’s being concerned that the plaintiff may have passed on intelligence which had caused the police to be suspicious about Treacy. There was no reason for the plaintiff to increase the remuneration offered to $15,000 if McDougall had earlier agreed to be part of the scheme for $1000. 208 Furthermore, according to McDougall, the plaintiff then volunteers information that the plaintiff was to receive $50,000. Why would he do so? In effect, the plaintiff is alleged to be asking McDougall to do work that the plaintiff himself has been engaged to do but if McDougall does the work satisfactorily he is to receive $15,000 but Holovinsky who was only a conduit on the scenario being painted by McDougall is to receive $50,000. One would think that if that were the case McDougall would be claiming that he also was entitled at least to that amount of $50,000. The conversation is implausible.209 The next thing is that it is alleged by McDougall that the plaintiff said that the plantation was “on top of a mountain”. When the plantations were found, they were found in the valley of the Yowrie River and the valley of Russell’s Creek and in adjoining areas. One does not find rivers and creeks on top of mountains. Even though I have had cause to criticise the plaintiff for his geographical ignorance, I am sure that he would be aware of that simple fact.210 Another thing I must compare my observations with certain evidence given by McDougall about this conversation. In exhibit 11, page 2478, McDougall gave evidence at trial that any conversation that he had with the plaintiff on 1 November was “in a long drinking session”. It was put by Mr Somosi to McDougall that by 7 o’clock the plaintiff was “legless” which received this response: 
     
      
      “I don’t recall him being. I have seen him very drunk in the past, I don’t recall him being very drunk that day.” 
      
    211 It is interesting that McDougall does not observe the state of the plaintiff’s sobriety. The person least able to ascertain another person’s state of sobriety is the person who is himself insober. Drunks do not generally realise that those with whom they are conversing are also drunk. It is only the sober who realises the extent of another’s drunkenness. Again, the inability of McDougall to be able to comment adequately on the plaintiff’s state of sobriety on 1 November 1990 indicates that McDougall himself may not have been very sober.212 McDougall said that he was not aware whether the cannabis crops were on top of the mountain or in valleys. He went on to agree that the plaintiff only ever spoke about a crop, according to McDougall and not to the four crops, or more than one crop, that were actually found. 213 On the following day, 2 November 1990, McDougall went on sick report for “stress”.
