On the day following, 3 November 1990, occurred the eight and a half hour conversation between McDougall and Detective Sergeant Krawczyk at licensed premises in Kiama between 4pm and 12.30am. Going back in my notes, my note for 12 October 1990 was of a meeting between McDougall and Krawczyk at the Group 7 Club at Kiama between 5 and 8pm. Accordingly, earlier I have made a mistake. The meeting on 12 October 1990 was a three hour meeting. The lengthy meeting that involved a meal and a drinking session occurred on 3 November 1990, two days after the meeting between McDougall and the plaintiff at the Court Tavern at Campbelltown and the day following McDougall’s going on sick report. Again, this was a second meeting between McDougall and Krawczyk in which Krawczyk sought to encourage McDougall to continue in the course of action that had been proposed by the police force in investigating McDougall’s allegations against the plaintiff.214 The next contact, it would appear, between the plaintiff and McDougall was on 22 November 1990, some time prior to 4 o’clock. The text of that conversation can be found in exhibit 11 at page 2506, at around line 54. At that time Mr Somosi was cross-examining McDougall about entries made in running sheets by Detective Sergeant Krawczyk and it contains a report to Detective Sergeant Krawczyk of a conversation alleged by McDougall with the plaintiff. This evidence was given: 
     
      
      “Q. Did you report to Krawczyk that the text of the conversation with Holovinsky was:  
      
     
     
      
      McDougall ‘Fred’ on the telephone. Holovinsky, ‘Bobby’. McDougall, ‘The fish are biting down here, lots of big fish.’ Holovinsky, ‘Where Nowra, Greenwell Point area?’ McDougall, ‘Batemans Bay area.’ Holovinsky, ‘Wrong fish. See you later’. McDougall, ‘Okay’.” 
      
    McDougall was asked whether he reported that conversation with the plaintiff to Krawczyk but McDougall said he did not remember the conversation. 215 The text of that conversation in the running sheet involved is found also at page 1295 of exhibit 6. According to the running sheet, the conversation occurred about 3.55pm. There are implausibilities about the conversation alleged. If I am to take “fish are biting” as meaning that police are making investigations, then Holovinsky is asking whether the police were making their investigations in the Nowra, Greenwell Point area. Why would the plaintiff be concerned about the Nowra, Greenwell Point area? That is nowhere near the area where the drug plantation actually was at Yowrie near Cobargo and Nowra and Greenwell Point have no other mention in the whole saga of the current matter.216 McDougall is then alleged to have told the plaintiff that the fish were biting in Batemans Bay to which the plaintiff replied, “Wrong fish”. If that is to mean that McDougall was saying that the police were making investigations at Batemans Bay, the plaintiff is alleged to have said that they were making their investigations in the wrong place but why would the plaintiff have brought up Nowra and Greenwell Point? It, to me, is implausible. 217 There was, in fact, an intercepted telephone conversation between the plaintiff and Treacy at 4.09pm. The conversation was about making arrangements to meet. The plaintiff suggests a meeting at about 11pm that evening or on the following afternoon at 3.30. Treacy agrees to meet the plaintiff at 11pm but it is common ground that the meeting did not occur at 11pm. Mr Treacy’s position in evidence before me is that he would never meet the plaintiff at such a late hour of the evening and it may be that Treacy merely agreed to do so in order to stop the plaintiff’s importuning him to do so. However, the plaintiff did offer an alternative of 3.30pm on the following day.218 At 7.15pm McDougall went to the Burwood RSL Club. At 7.25 he commenced a conversation there with the plaintiff. The conversation between the plaintiff and McDougall ended at 7.42 when the pair were said to return to talk to other people there. The plaintiff left the club at 8.40 and McDougall left the club at 8.55. Before and after meeting the plaintiff, McDougall met with Detective Sergeant Krawczyk at the Three Swallows Hotel at Bankstown. On McDougall’s return to the Three Swallows Hotel at Bankstown, McDougall made notes of his conversation which were countersigned by Krawczyk although he was not present at the conversation.219 The conversation was a lengthy one. The notes made by McDougall are Exhibit 48. The text of the conversation is set out in paragraphs 27 to 30 of McDougall’s statement. Unfortunately it is necessary to consider the text. It is this:  
     
      
      27. I said, “Fred, I’ve got good news and bad news. What do you want first?” He said “The bad news.” I said “A dry job is kicking off soon covering the entire south coast. We’re going down the coast and back up inland.” He said, “When?”. I said “December. Do you want the good news?” He said “Yeah.” I said “I’m running the job”. He said “You fucking beauty. How do you mean?” I said “Beauy [Detective Senior Sergeant Beaumont] and some other prick with fruit salad on the shoulders sail another commissioned police officer] came down the other day and put it on me to get involved in the job. All I know is that it kicks off in early December and is going to go three weeks. Bobby it won’t kill me if it’s not there.” He said “Mate. Bobby. Christmas and we are all laughing.” I said “Okay, I’m happy with that. We better get back to the others.”” 
      
    220 To have had such a conversation occurring between 7.25pm and 7.42pm, to then stay at the RSL perhaps taking food and liquid refreshment until 8.55, then travelling from Burwood RSL Club to the Three Swallows Hotel at Bankstown and then sitting down in that hotel and writing out the conversation would require a prodigious memory which would be the envy of the world. It is quite implausible firstly for McDougall to have remembered all that conversation as he has set it out.221 At this point it is important to note some of the matters that were elicited from McDougall in cross-examination by Mr Somosi. At page 2519 of Exhibit 11 this evidence was given:  
     
      
      “Q. Yet he is offering you up to this point, increasing amounts of money to protect a crop, in a location he never specifically described.  
      
     
     
      
      Q. Is that correct? Yes. Is that correct?  
       
      A. Yes, that would be right.  
      
    222 That is in fact implausible. At pages 2522 to 2525 McDougall was cross-examined about taking sick leave for stress at this time. He was on stress leave on 2 November, 3 November and visited the psychologist, Mr Glancey, on 15 November and on 20 November and on 22 November the very day that this conversation is alleged to have occurred. At page 2527, at line 20, McDougall agreed that the plaintiff was not ‘hassling’ him at all. Commencing at page 2528 Mr Somosi cross-examined the plaintiff about the reference to the helicopter pilot. This is quite implausible. What is attributed to the plaintiff implies that Holovinsky knew an operation was impending, or was to occur, that a helicopter was to be involved and that there was only one pilot who would be flying the helicopter. At page 2532 of exhibit 11 McDougall conceded that there were a number of helicopter pilots that might be available. One should note in the conversation also a regurgitation of matters that had already been discussed and agreed, for example whether McDougall was to be involved in the scheme, whether he was willing to take part and how much was the consideration for his involvement was. There is an air of unreality in the whole of the conversation recorded by McDougall.223 The plaintiff’s case about the meeting at the Burwood RSL was attacked by the defendant on the basis of, why it was necessary to meet at the Burwood RSL Club? The evidence is not clear to me as to who made the arrangements. However, it is patently clear that both Mr McDougall and the plaintiff were quite interested in having a drink and the suggestion for the meeting at that place could have been made by either of them.224 The plaintiff was on duty at Newtown, his licence had been cancelled. He was driven to Burwood by a probationary constable, who was clearly acting as his chauffeur. The police vehicle was parked in the Burwood Police Station. Both the plaintiff and the probationary constable walked together to the RSL Club. They were met there by McDougall. The plaintiff removed his appointments and changed his shirt at the Burwood Police Station, but I have already discussed that scenario when referring to the plaintiff’s visit to the Five Dock Hotel on 15 January 1990.225 The clear inference to be drawn from paragraph 26 of McDougall’s statement is that this was another venue frequented by policemen. No doubt during the time that those performing afternoon shift were entitled to have their meal break, a policeman might frequent the RSL Club. Bearing in mind that so many meetings between police occurred at licensed premises, this I do not find as surprising as did counsel for the defendant. 226 Furthermore, the fact that the plaintiff took the probationary constable along with him to the Burwood RSL Club it does suggest that as far as the plaintiff was concerned there was going to be no conversation about some illegal activity. If there was an intention to discuss some illegal activity the best thing would have been to direct the probationary constable to stay at the Burwood Police Station.227 The criticism that the defendant made in that regard can equally be rebutted by the fact that when it was necessary for McDougall to confer with Detective Sergeant Krawczyk, before and after this meeting, that meeting was not held at the Bankstown Police Station, but at the Three Swallows Hotel at Bankstown. 228 On 25 November 1990 Henry Charles Landini, also known as Little Danny, was arrested. He was arrested for ‘stick-ups’, that is armed robberies. I am unaware as to whether the armed robberies were on the South Coast, or in Sydney. The evidence concerning that arrest can be found in the evidence of Mr Treacy.229 On 28 November 1990 McDougall travelled to Bega, with Detective Sergeant Beaumont. The vehicle was that of Detective Sergeant Beaumont, probably a police vehicle assigned to him. Detective Sergeant Beaumont picked McDougall up at his home at about 8 o’clock. At 8.21 McDougall alleges that he made a telephone call to the plaintiff. 230 According to McDougall’s evidence the telephone conversation was made when the car was stationary at the Pleasant Point Lookout, just south of Kiama, near the big water towers that are at that place. The telephone call was made on a mobile telephone that was supplied by Detective Sergeant Beaumont to McDougall. This was not the usual mobile telephone used by Detective Sergeant Beaumont, as he had swapped it with the mobile telephone of some other squad. The conversation, according to McDougall was this: 
     
      
      “I said ‘Fred? It’s Bob.’ He said ‘Hello mate.’ I said ‘Fred, I’m on my way down the coast to do this drug job.’ He said ‘Where you going?’ I said ‘I don’t know yet, I haven’t been briefed.’ He said ‘Who’s with you?’ I said ‘Gary Beaumont.’ He said ‘What’s happening down there?’ I said ‘Just a conference at this stage. We’re meeting some intelligence blokes down there.’ He said ‘Did you hear that bloke, Landini, is off down there?’ I said ‘What do you mean?’ He said ‘He got locked up for stick-ups.’ I said ‘Bullshit, for real?’ He said ‘Yeah. Have you heard anything?’ I said ‘No. This is the first. When?’ He said ‘The other day. I don’t know much about it yet.’ I said ‘Mate, I told you he was no good. He’s going to bring it all down around our ears.’ He said ‘Yeah. He’s a cunt. But it’ll be all right. Keep your eyes and ears open. See if you can find anything down there.’ I said ‘Yeah, I don’t know much yet. But after the meeting I’ll be a big smarter.’ He said ‘Call me then, will you?’ I said ‘I’ll try to call you about one, all right?’ He said ‘Yeah, yeah, keep in touch’.” 
      
    He finished the call and then made some notes of the conversation. Those notes are exhibit 49 before me. There is controversy over the notes. The controversy concerns an inconsistency between the evidence of McDougall and Detective Sergeant Beaumont. Detective Sergeant Beaumont said that parts of the notes were made as the car was being driven, that although when McDougall commenced to make the notes the car was stationary, the car moved off at some stage before the notes were completed. McDougall says they were completed whilst the car was stationary.231 When looks at the notes there is no suggestion whatever that they were made or any part of them was made in a moving vehicle. The important thing to note about this conversation is that the plaintiff informs McDougall that Landini has been arrested. McDougall alleges that he was concerned that as Landini had been party to the arrangement he could do the enterprise mischief, that he might give away information about the enterprise, which could lead to its being discovered.232 On the afternoon of the same day there was a telephone call made by the plaintiff to McDougall at the Bega Village Motor Inn. The time of the call was 3.43pm eastern standard time, but summer time would have then been applicable, so the call actually occurred at 4.43pm. The conversation is lengthy and I decline to quote it in full. McDougall advised the plaintiff that he was in Bega and that there was to be a conference down there. He said that amongst those attending the conference were members of the drug squad from Queanbeyan and Intelligence officers from Merimbula. What was on the agenda was to select the order of places that were to be investigated.233 At page 1308 of exhibit 6 the following part of the conversation occurs. I should indicate that V2 indicates the plaintiff and V3 indicates McDougall: 
     
      
      “V2: ‘Mate, you know that Danny Landini was, have you heard about Danny Landini down there, he’s at Mystery Bay apparently, he’s got a farm down there, a crop?’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘No, I haven’t heard mate, I haven’t heard at all, I’ve had me ears open all day, but I’ve heard nothing about it.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘Well what happened last week, he apparently has gone to see somebody at Mystery Bay, or somewhere, wherever he is, at Eden is it, does he live down there somewhere?’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘I don’t know, Eden’s down here mate, yeah, but I don’t know where Mystery Bay is.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘I don’t know, well anyhow he’s gone to see a copper down there, and are to do, gone to do business out at his farm, and the coppers approached another copper and the copper’s gone to I.A., so they’re all down there at the moment.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘Down where? Say that again?’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘Danny Landini, the crook, you know he’s a crook?’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘I know he’s a crook.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘Yeah, apparently he’s been doing stick-ups up here too, him and a fella called Ray Riley, have you heard of him down there?’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘Nah.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘Well he’s another crook too, they’re both running together, they’re coming up to Sydney apparently doing stick-ups, this is the information that I got yesterday. And apparently are what, what Dan Landini has done, he’s gone to see a copper down there, right? I don’t know who it is, but are to get, get him to look after some crop he has got growing down there. And this policeman’s gone to see somebody else and the bloke’s gone to see I.A., they’re all down there.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘Oh fuck, I told you he’s fucking bad news.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘Landini?’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘Yeah.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘Oh he’s no good at all.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘Fuck me dead.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘Yeah, yeah mate’.” 
      
    234 The same sort of matter is again conveyed to McDougall by the plaintiff on page 1310. It became clear that he there refers to an informant, but that was not his usual informant, Treacy, but in fact Mr Rod Moore. The plaintiff also passes on information that Landini may be a heroin importer and have fishing boats down at Eden, or one of his associates may have. 235 At page 1311 the following occurs: 
     
      
      “V3: ‘Mate, well where does that, where does that put us with this fucking Landini cunt?’ 
      
     
     
      
      V2: ‘Well we want him to go off.’ 
      
     
     
      
      V3: ‘Fuckin’ oath, just get him out of the fuckin’ way for Christ’s sake’.” 
      
    The reference by the plaintiff to wanting Landini to ‘go off’ is a reference to his being arrested.236 What comes through from reading that telephone intercepted call is that the plaintiff was supplying information to McDougall about Landini and it is clear that Landini was badly regarded, to put it mildly, by the plaintiff and that that the plaintiff was happy for Landini to be arrested. 237 During cross-examination by Mr Somosi about this telephone conversation McDougall gave the following answers: 
     
      
      “Q. ‘I suggest to you that what was occurring here was a theme which interested Holovinsky, as far as you were concerned in September, continued through October and November and it relates to getting and trapping Landini, and you and he getting credit for it, correct?’  
       
      A. ‘It went that way eventually, yes. 
      
    238 Part of the telephone intercept was then played to McDougall and he agreed that when the plaintiff used the words “We want him to go off” was that he wanted Landini to be arrested.239 At page 2565 of exhibit 11 this evidence was given: 
     
      
      “Q. ‘And you said “just get him out of the way for Christ’s sake” was the suggestion by you to get Landini off the scene?’  
       
      A. ‘Yes.’  
      
     
     
      
      Q. ‘Get him locked up?’  
       
      A. ‘Yes’.  
      
     
     
      
      Q. ‘Get him put away?’  
       
      A. ‘Yes’.” 
      
    240 In effect there is a discrepancy between the morning conversation of 28 November and the afternoon conversation of 28 November. The afternoon conversation cannot be doubted and is not doubted. The afternoon conversation is consistent with the plaintiff’s case mounted before me, and indeed at the criminal trial, and is inconsistent with the inferences to be drawn, or that McDougall would seek one to draw, from the conversation of the morning of 28 November for the exactitude of which one is totally reliant upon McDougall.241 In the conversation McDougall went on to tell the plaintiff about the areas that were to be covered by this drug sweep along the coast of New South Wales. This was misinformation being conveyed by McDougall in his role as a corrupt cop. However, the misinformation contained information which suggested that the area where the drug crop was would be searched, that is covered the area of Cobargo, Yowrie and the Wadbilliga National Park immediately west of Yowrie.242 In cross-examination McDougall admitted that Mr Holovinsky expressed no concern when McDougall disclosed the area which included, the area where the drug crop was. The important thing about that is that as far as these telephone intercepts are concerned the tapes are no longer available to hear. They were clearly played at the committal proceedings and clearly played at the trial and clearly re-played over and over at the trial.243 Ms Stenmark, for the defendant, had some of the tapes, but they were no longer intelligible and that is completely understandable because they were, as far as the hearing before me is concerned, recorded 16 and 17 years previously on what would now be outmoded technology and had been repeatedly played since that time. One could understand that the tapes are no longer able to be heard, that therefore comments made by those who actually heard the tapes are of utility in helping one to determine the current matter.244 Clearly one’s voice, or response, can carry a tone or inflection, or volume, which might indicate panic, or alarm, joy, or happiness. It is clear that there was no concern expressed by the plaintiff when information was given which would indicate that the area where the drug plantation actually was to be searched.245 At the end of the conversation the plaintiff volunteered to ring McDougall at the Bega Police Station on the following day. It still appears to be odd that an alleged criminal conspirator would want to speak to another alleged criminal conspirator at a police station where the calls might be monitored, or where the identities of the caller and the person called might be known to other police. 246 There were on the following day, 29 November 1990 two further phone calls between the plaintiff and McDougall. Neither of these phone calls was recorded. The notes of McDougall for these conversations are exhibit 51 before me. The first call is alleged to have occurred at 9.16am, when McDougall called the plaintiff at the Newtown Police Station from the Bega Valley Motor Inn. 247 In the first part of the alleged conversation McDougall relates areas where the search was to be conducted, that mimics to an extent what was actually said in the conversation on the previous afternoon. McDougall then records some information about Landini and others, that McDougall obtained from the local detectives. Part of the conversation, according to McDougall, was this: 
     
      
      “’I said I’ll be here. Before you go, can you speak to your mate about Landini? I still don’t trust him.’ He said ‘Don’t worry, he’s off.’ I said ‘The money?’ He said ‘I’m talking to my mate this afternoon about that?’ I said ‘The crop, I got to know where not to look, don’t I?’ He said ‘I don’t know where it is myself. I’ll speak to him’.” 
      
    248 The interesting thing about that alleged interchange is that it became clear from earlier recorded interchanges, if they be accurate, that at least by 22 November, in the conversation at the Burwood RSL Club, that Landini was out of the syndicate of cannabis growers, that he had been excluded and that attempts were being made to ensure, according to McDougall, that he would not pass on intelligence about the cannabis crop to the authorities. McDougall’s saying what he said ignores what had earlier passed between him and Holovinsky on this issue, according to McDougall. In other words there is an internal inconsistency in McDougall’s recounting of these conversations.249 McDougall’s evidence is that at about 3.45pm he returned to the motel from, the police station, and received a handwritten message from the manager of the Bega Valley Motor Inn to ring Fred on a given telephone number. That is obviously to ring the plaintiff. McDougall says he phoned the plaintiff at the given number, which was that of the Court Tavern. Again, there was alleged to be a lengthy conversation between McDougall and the plaintiff, which was subsequently recorded by McDougall in his notes.250 According to McDougall the first thing discussed was McDougall’s getting his money and again the plaintiff was alleged to have told him that he would have to wait. McDougall then says he set out and he described more things about the alleged drug sweep, that is, related more misinformation, then gave some misinformation about when it was to happen. And in the middle of that the plaintiff is alleged to have said, ‘Listen, give us a yell if you go anywhere near Cobargo. Right.’ To which McDougall gave a positive response.251 McDougall then said that the plaintiff asked whether that name had been mentioned at the police meeting on that day. McDougall maintained that the name was only mentioned in passing. 252 The subject of Landini was then raised. The plaintiff had told McDougall that his informant had told him that Landini had a couple of crops at Mystery Bay. One will recall that that had earlier been mentioned. The plaintiff was trying to obtain information as to the exact whereabouts of those two crops belonging to Landini and then expressed the desire that Landini be arrested with those crops. The conversation is alleged to have gone on further with the plaintiff’s saying: 
     
      
      “If you can knock Landini, it will be a beauty.” 
      
    Parts of that conversation are consistent with what the plaintiff says that he was always intending, to have Landini arrested. According to McDougall, this is the first time that the plaintiff mentioned Cobargo. I have already accepted that it was more probable than not that that was raised by the plaintiff in his initial meeting with McDougall on 28 September.253 There is much force in the submissions put both by Mr Gross to me and it could be gleaned that may have been put by Mr Somosi from the way he cross-examined Mr McDougall at the trial that the name Cobargo was dropped into the conversation by McDougall to lend it an air of verisimilitude. 254 On 30 November 1990, McDougall returned from Bega on a Pioneer bus. At 11.30pm on the evening of that day, he made a phone call to the plaintiff at the Newtown Police Station. The phone call was made from McDougall’s home and an attempt was made to record the conversation. Unfortunately, there was a mal-recording of the conversation and only one side of it was recorded. That side was McDougall’s. This was described at the trial as the one-sided conversation. 255 The cross-examination of McDougall concerning this one-sided conversation can be found in exhibit 12 between pages 2628 and 2636. At 2632, McDougall agreed that he was talking about information he had obtained from the plaintiff in the recorded telephone conversation of 28 November 1990 in this one-sided conversation. He was really bringing up again the information previously conveyed by the plaintiff to McDougall about Landini. 256 On page 2633, McDougall admitted that he was talking about Landini when he referred to a person being hated down the South Coast and of a person having a machine gun down the South Coast. At the foot of page 2634, carrying on to 2635, McDougall agreed that the plaintiff was suggesting that police should follow Landini in light of his having a machine gun. At page 2635, the following evidence was given: 
     
      
       “Q. Well up to this point of the conversation, the entire conversation, in effect, from the last third of the first page to this point is very focused clearly on Landini?” 
       
      A. Yes, but that is not the entire conversation. I agree with what you said then, but it was not what you said to me.” 
      
    When one reads the one-sided conversation and the cross-examination that Mr Somosi conducted on Mr McDougall about it, the conversation does not have, in my view, any sinister aspect. That is, any aspect which is inconsistent with the thrust of the plaintiff’s evidence before me.257 Before turning to the events of December 1990 I shall take the luncheon adjournment.258 As I was rising to take a short adjournment, Ms Stenmark of counsel was kind enough to draw my attention to a factual error I have made.259 In reference to the conversation at the Burwood RSL club on 22 November 1990 I made reference to the plaintiff’s taking with him to that meeting a probationary constable who was acting as his chauffeur. The plaintiff had need of the chauffeur because of having lost his driver’s licence. The plaintiff’s evidence, at page 143 of the transcript of 9 December 2004, is that the plaintiff had with him a young probationary constable whose wife was sick and who lived at Burwood. The probationary constable wanted to see his wife and, after driving to Burwood police station, the probationary constable went to see his wife and the plaintiff went to the RSL.260 However, it is clear from page 1296 of exhibit 6 that during the conversation between the plaintiff and McDougall on 22 November 1990 a Detective Sergeant Long from the Five Dock police station and a young probationary constable were present, albeit that neither of those men were present at the time of this private conversation between the plaintiff and McDougall.261 Mr Gross advises that his understanding of the evidence was that the probationary constable returned to the RSL after visiting his wife and was present there for some time prior to leaving with the plaintiff. Commonsense indicates that that was probably the case because the plaintiff could not return to Newtown police station without his chauffeur, the probationary constable, and the probationary constable would need to meet up with the plaintiff after visiting his wife so that the plaintiff would know that his chauffeur was available to take him back to Newtown police station.262 I did not mean to suggest that either the probationary constable or any other person listened to this conversation, merely that they were present in the club at the time that the plaintiff and McDougall were meeting. It still remains that the plaintiff and McDougall met at a place where there might be, and in fact were, other policemen and Detective Sergeant Long, in this case from Five Dock, and that clearly the probationary constable returned to the RSL club so that the meeting, the fact that the plaintiff and McDougall met at the RSL club, could not be disputed.263 Prior to taking the adjournment I indicated that I was about to turn to events of December 1990, but I should indicate, before I do so, that the evidence discloses that on Thursday 29 November, at 3.03pm, the plaintiff entered the bistro area of the Court Tavern and then, at 3.30pm, walked from the bistro area to the public bar, where he approached a number of people seating and standing near the bar. One of those persons was Treacy. The plaintiff had a brief conversation with Treacy there and left the public bar area via the rear entrance. He returned to the public bar at 3.43pm. There were two police carrying out surveillance at the time. That establishes a meeting on 29 November 1990 between the plaintiff and Treacy when it is to be recalled that McDougall phoned the plaintiff at 4.45pm on that same day from Bega in answer to a request to phone the plaintiff at the Court Tavern left at the Bega Motor Inn by the plaintiff.264 What may have been the reason for that meeting? It is clear that from the time of the arrest of Landini for armed robberies on 25 November there was some breaking news. Clearly Gravener and perhaps his associates on the South Coast would want to know what was happening about Landini and perhaps want to know about his bail status. It may be that Gravener spoke to Treacy who then needed to seek further information from the plaintiff, who was obtaining his information in that regard not from Treacy but from Rod Moore. And one can understand conversations of discussions at this time as to what was happening about Landini.265 On 5 December 1990 there were a number of intercepted telephone conversations. The first was at 7pm from Treacy to the plaintiff where Treacy was advised the plaintiff was in the bath. At 7.13pm the plaintiff rang Treacy and was advised that Treacy had gone out. At 7.14 Treacy phoned the plaintiff back and Treacy told the plaintiff that he wanted to have “a yarn”. They arranged to meet at either 12 noon or lunch time on the following day. At 10.37pm McDougall phoned the plaintiff to confirm a meeting for the following day. The plaintiff told McDougall he was playing golf in the morning and that he was meeting a fellow for lunch at 12 o’clock and that McDougall did not want to be there. That clearly is a reference to the meeting that had been arranged between Treacy and the plaintiff. McDougall and the plaintiff arranged to meet between 3.00 and 3.30 on the following day.266 What engendered these telephone discussions was an event that was described both at the trial and in this hearing as the Yowrie bail-up. The best description of the bail-up is at page 70 of the transcript of 1 August 2006. Gravener came across people on his property with knapsacks, surveillance gear and other gear which include camping gear and camouflage gear. Gravener bailed up these people with his rifle. There were twelve of them. Eventually one of them produced his police identity card. The twelve were taken by Gravener, or went with Gravener to the local police station. That was the first description given by Mr Treacy, who then gave this evidence: 
     
      
       
        
       
      
     
     
      
      “Q. What did he do then? 
       
      A. He bailed one person up he found on his property with surveillance things. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. But then he found the others were there? 
       
      A. He asked him what he was doing. He said he was with the army. He walked him back to his car, and then the man pulled his identification out and said ‘I’m with the police’. Mark then put his stuff in the back of the thing and said ‘Ring the police and tell them to come down here’. He got on his two-way and then the rest of them came down to the car.” 
      
    267 Clearly there were police in the vicinity of Gravener’s holding at Yowrie conducting surveillance. Whether they were looking for Landini or for Gravener, I do not know. Clearly Gravener thought that they were observing him. From the presence of surveillance gear, it is clear that they were not there merely to search for a drug plantation. One would think that that intelligence was communicated by Gravener to Treacy and Treacy then arranged to meet with Holovinsky to discuss this development. For some reason or other there had been arrangements made between McDougall and the plaintiff to meet on 6 December and it was now scheduled to meet at about 3:00pm or 3.30pm, after the plaintiff had met with Treacy.268 Page 1390 of exhibit 6 is a police running sheet which confirms that an observation post had been set up on Mark Gravener’s property and that a search of the relevant area on 5 December 1990 failed to locate any plantation. Police surveillance confirms that the plaintiff and Treacy met at the Court Tavern at 2.08pm and conversed from that time until 2.25pm, when they shook hands and Treacy left the bistro of the Tavern and went to the public car park. McDougall entered the Tavern at 3.25pm wearing a listening device. The transcript of the recording made by that listening device between 3.22 and 3.50 is in exhibit 6 pages 1393 to 1408.269 The first part of that transcript records the conversation of no moment other than general interest between the plaintiff, McDougall and one gentleman known as Pidge and another gentleman known as Meatloaf. The relevant conversation commences at page 1400. The relevant part of the conversation occurs after background noises are recorded. ‘V1’ is McDougall and ‘V2’ is the plaintiff: 
     
      
      “V1: What? 
      
     
     
      
      V2: Listen, don’t take any offence (indecipherable).  
      
     
     
      
      V1: Why is that? 
      
     
     
      
      V2: I’m fucking paranoid. 
      
     
     
      
      V1: Fucking so am I. 
      
     
     
      
      V2: Mate, you know what’s happened, don’t you?” 
      
    The conversation continues with the plaintiff’s conveying to McDougall information about the Yowrie bail-up. The original tape is, like every other tape, not available to listen to. It is clear from the transcript of the trial, exhibit 12 page 2098 before me, that after the words “I’m fucking paranoid” the plaintiff said “You are not taped up, are you?”270 This was the first and only occasion on which McDougall wore a listening device. He had been directed by Assistant Commissioner Cole to wear a listening device but refused or declined to do so and was finally coerced on this occasion to wear the listening device. He said he did not like wearing one. The plaintiff’s case at trial was that McDougall did not wish to wear a listening device because the listening device would not record the sort of conversations that McDougall had been reporting the plaintiff as having held. 271 McDougall alleged that during the words “listen, don’t take any offence”, the plaintiff was searching McDougall for a listening device. In his evidence-in-chief, in exhibit 12 page 2362, McDougall said this: 
     
      
      “At the beginning of this conversation the accused was sitting opposite me. He searched my upper body. He reached out with his left hand and patted me under my right arm. He then ran his hand over my chest in the vicinity of my right shirt pocket, took hold of the piece of electronic wire taped to my chest and the fold in my shirt, he felt the wire and ran his fingers up the wire towards the top of the pocket. He then let the wire go and continued with the conversation. The whole of this conversation was recorded on the listening device.” 
      
    McDougall went on in-chief to say he was extremely concerned for his own safety at that time.272 If that had occurred, one would have thought that the plaintiff knew that McDougall was wired up and that he would have desisted from any incriminating conversation thereafter and would have told McDougall to go home using very colourful language. 273 McDougall was extensively cross-examined about there being no noises recorded on the tape to suggest that the listening device was being tampered with and such noises do appear in other places on the tape, especially at the commencement of it when McDougall was adjusting the wire underneath his clothing, when he was entering the hotel and at the end when he was taking the device from his body before actually switching it off. Furthermore, why would the plaintiff ask McDougall “You are not taped up, are you?” if he knew that the plaintiff was taped up?274 The implausibility here is the allegation by McDougall that the plaintiff searched him and actually felt the tapes of the wire body tap. That is highly improbable. Furthermore, the tape itself does not disclose the appropriate noises. I accept that Mr Holovinsky did ask, as Mr Holovinsky admitted at the trial, “whether McDougall was taped up or not”, but I do not accept the assertion of McDougall that he was actually searched and the body wire was found.275 In the transcript of the trial there is also extensive cross-examination as to where the pair were seated and whether it was possible for Mr Holovinsky to have reached over and searched McDougall, bearing in mind the intervening table and their respective sizes. The evidence of McDougall about the search and discovery of the wire is completely implausible.276 Equally, there are areas of evidence before me from the plaintiff which are equally implausible. He sought to maintain that what he meant by the words “I’m fucking paranoid” is that he was suffering from disappointment. His evidence was given commencing at page 194 of the transcript of 13 December 2004: 
     
      
      “Q. Why did you say to him ‘I’m fucking paranoid’? 
       
      A. You will have to look at it in the whole context ma’am. That’s a stage in the afternoon. I am drunk and having a talk with him. I have received certain information and he’s doing nothing. He’s telling me nothing. Nothing’s happening. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. You and McDougall lowered your voices at the time you had this part of the conversation, didn’t you? 
       
      A. No. 
      
     
     
      
       
        
       
      
     
     
      
      Q. Do you say now on your oath that you didn’t? 
       
       
      GROSS: Didn’t what? 
      
     
     
      
      STENMARK: Q. Lower your voices at the time you had that conversation? 
       
      A. To the best of my recollection that’s correct.” 
      
    The plaintiff was then taken to his evidence at committal and admitted to saying yes at that time. In other words, the plaintiff started out giving evidence to me which was inconsistent with his evidence at trial.277 The questioning then continued. At 196: 
     
      
      “Q. Mr Holovinsky, with the doubts in relation to McDougall, I take it came the worry about what he was doing? 
       
      A. I don’t know what I was worried about but what he, about what he was doing. It was probably what he wasn’t doing. 
       
       
      Q. Anxious at what he wasn’t doing? 
       
      A. What are we talking now, about this particular moment here, yes.  
      
     
     
      
      Q. By 6 December you tell the magistrate that you have complete doubts about him? 
       
      A. Yes. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. And with those doubts, I’m putting to you came worry and pressure to you? 
       
      A. Not worry and pressure, just.  
      
     
     
      
      Q. Anxious? 
       
      A. Disappointment. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. Disappointment? 
       
      A. Yes. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. What did you do about your disappointment? 
       
      A. I was just waiting.  
      
     
     
      
      Q. Did you start to panic about the fact that he may have been setting you up? 
       
      A. No, he had nothing to set me up for. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. See, I’m putting to you directly that you started to worry that he was setting you up and that’s why you told him you were fucking paranoid? 
       
      A. No. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. That’s why you frisked him? 
       
      A. I didn’t frisk him. 
      
     
     
      
      Q. If you were having doubts about him why didn’t you go and report the matter to someone else? 
       
      A. Once you pass on information that’s how it goes. That’s how it stays. You wait for a result. That’s the usual way things are done.” 
      
    278 I find that evidence unsatisfactory in the extreme. When one looks at the rest of the taped conversation, it is clear that it was after the Yowrie bail-up. It is clear that after the plaintiff had a meeting with Treacy, Treacy had already had a meeting with the plaintiff at which Treacy may well have voiced his concerns to the plaintiff about surveillance on Treacy after Treacy had spoken to Holovinsky. The aid of Treacy had been invoked by Gravener to try to keep Landini from his property and so that police would not “raid” his property. Police were now near Gravener’s property. In other words, what Gravener did not want to happen had happened and he no doubt voiced his concern about that to Treacy, who no doubt voiced his concern about that to the plaintiff. The plaintiff may have been thoroughly concerned that these two events were linked to his disclosing his information to McDougall. That appears to be the most likely scenario. 279 I return to the telephone intercept.280 One of the interchanges that might be thought to be damning was this: 
     
      
      “V2: Where’s the area I said not to go near. Remember I said, fucking I mention an area. 
       
       
      V1: You said Cobargo. 
       
       
      V2: There they are.” 
      
    281 The plaintiff explains this by saying that the idea was to get Landini at the site of the plantation, or crop, but here are the police there when Landini was not. That was what he was driving at. The telephone conversation goes on to record that “everybody in the fucking town knows they’re there”, meaning everybody in Cobargo and the area knew.282 During the conversation McDougall was at pains to tell the plaintiff that the police at the scene were nothing to do with his operation, the fictitious operation which he had been feeding to the plaintiff. This occurs on page 1403: 
     
      
      “V2: Well nobody knows about it, see that’s what’s fucking been so fucking wrong, that nobody’s ever gone down there ‘til fucking I spoke to you. 
      
     
     
      
      V1: Mate, I’m telling you they’re not our fucking blokes, take it for what it’s worth, they’re not our fucking blokes. 
       
        
       
      
     
     
      
      V2: Well nobody else (indecipherable). 
       
       
      V1: I’m not a fucking magician pal. 
       
       
      V2: I’m not saying (indecipherable) suggesting that to you, right. I’m just fucking suggesting to you that this bloke said to me (indecipherable) Fred, they won’t get a fucking pinch, it’s as simple as that. Fucking all that is going to fucking happen is fucking if whatever happens happens they won’t get a pinch, so it’s not going to do anybody any good. Do you understand what I mean? 
      
     
     
      
      V1: Mate, I’m (indecipherable) fucked, [blasphemy deleted].  
      
     
     
      
      V2: Yeah, I got no idea what’s happening. Mate I just relay what I’m fucking told.” 
      
    That interchange can be read in a number of ways. The reference to there being no pinch down there might mean that there be no arrest of Landini. It could also mean that there might be no arrest of somebody else down there because the person is absent from the crop. One party before me says to take it in the first way and the other party says to take it in another way. 283 The conversation then turns to McDougall suggesting he would speak to someone known as Sam Leckey who could find out what is going on. The plaintiff declined that and continued: 
     
      
      “I just fucking, I don’t know whether fucking (indecipherable) everything was good Bob you know but apparently, apparently for five fucking years it was good and this bloke tried to fucking just do everything right to make sure everything was sweet and all of a sudden fucking just things have turned shit. 
      
     
     
      
      V1: Mate if they have turned shit it’s not from our fucking end. 
       
       
      V2: You look, I mean you look at it this way, like look at it this man’s point of view, he’s not spoken to anybody fucking at any other time, all of a sudden they’re trying to do the fucking right thing and it’s fucking turned to shit, how do you get around that.” 
      
    Again there are various interpretations open to that exchange. It might mean that Gravener had had no police attention for five years and then sought to do the right thing by giving information that could lead to Landini’s being apprehended, and then things went sour when Gravener became the source of police attention again. It may also, of course, indicate that the cannabis plantation was not under surveillance and then information was given to McDougall by the plaintiff and then things have come undone because the police have now turned up, searching for crops and carrying out observations. However, that construction of that interchange gives little value to the words “just doing everything right”, or it could have some sinister criminal content.284 Further in the conversation there is a reference to Landini, who might be giving information, or whether it was Treacy who might be giving information. Then McDougall raises the question of whether a helicopter pilot was talking to somebody. The plaintiff then says: 
     
      
      “No, nothing’s happened, nobody knows nothing. Look I don’t have no idea whether it is right. No idea about nothing. I’m just fucking saying to you, I look at all these bloody things and I just, you know, can’t, just can’t see fucking why tell me anything. I’ve got no idea I just fucking Landini, Landini fucking is a target down there but obviously he’s fucking not.” 
      
    That clearly is a statement by the plaintiff consistent with the plaintiff’s case at trial and before me and which is not open to any other construction.285 McDougall then offered to go and make a phone call to find out what was happening from the police point of view. The plaintiff then said this: 
     
      
      “Hang on, hang on, listen to me, no shit hit the fan, all I’m saying to you is that there are at now, there is only place they are looking at, the bloke that fucking rang and told him he’s been in it for fucking years, he knows it like the back of his hand, he went down there while the cunts were away to check and checked out their fucking knapsacks and there’s no cunt there, he’s seen all the fucking surveillance gear, all the fucking camouflage fucking gear, the whole fucking lot. You know they won’t get a pinch, it’s as simple as that, there’ll be no pinch there.” 
      
    That might mean, of course, that there will be no arrest of Landini because the police presence is so obvious and patent, or it could mean that because Gravener, who is the person who has obviously found the equipment, knows the police are there that no-one will be arrested in connection with this crop.286 The next few interchanges are not particularly relevant, but interchanges occurring on page 140 of exhibit 6 are relevant. They are these: 
     
      
      “V2: Well there’s no fuck up you see as I said to you there’s no fuck up. Nobody is going to get pinched out of it. The only thing we’re concerned about is that (indecipherable) ‘cause he’s fucking saying to these blokes down there, mate everything’s sweet, this is what’s happening, remember the last conversation we had about where you’re going to go and that sort of stuff. 
      
     
     
      
      V1: Mmm. 
       
       
      V2: Now everybody was extremely fucking happy

title: Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Craig Gillon [2007] NSWDC 76
content:
New South WalesDistrict Court 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
  
   
    
   CITATION: 
   Australian Broadcasting Corporation v Craig Gillon [2007] NSWDC 76 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   HEARING DATE(S): 
   01/05/07 
   
   
    
    EX TEMPORE JUDGMENT DATE : 
    1 May 2007 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   JURISDICTION: 
   Civil 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   JUDGMENT OF: 
   Gibson DCJ  
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   DECISION: 
   1. Grant leave to file Notice of Motion in the Registry subject to the registry ascertaining from the Dubbo District Court file number(s) for any criminal proceedings brought against Craig Gillon in that court; 2. Dispense with service on the DPP by reason of the consent of the respondent Craig Gillon to publication; 3. Notice of Motion dismissed; 4. These orders to be entered forthwith.  
   
   
    
    
    
   
  
 
 
  
   
    
   CATCHWORDS: 
   Criminal law – Publication orders – application for orders under s11(4)(b)(i) Children (Criminal Proceedings) Act 1987 – time at which order should be sought - documentary portraying discussion by Aboriginal adolescents of concerns about going to jail – publication does not connect the person with the criminal proceedings concerned – no order under s.11(4)(b)(i) required 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   LEGISLATION CITED: 
   Children (Criminal Proceedings) Act 1987 (NSW), s.11Family Law Act 1975 (Cth) s. 121 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   CASES CITED: 
   Application by John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd re MSK, MAK, MMK and MRK [2006] NSWCCA 386Markisic v AEA Ethnic Media Publications Pty Ltd & Ors [2007] NSWCA 378 Regina v Hart (Supreme Court of NSW, Common Law Division, Hulme J, 7 July 2006) 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   PARTIES: 
   Applicant: Australian Broadcasting Corporation  
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   FILE NUMBER(S): 
   No. 1752 of 2007 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   COUNSEL:  
   Applicant: S. Dawson 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   SOLICITORS:  
   ABC Legal Services  
   
   
    
    
    
   
  
 
 
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
 
 
  
   
    
   1. This morning I heard an urgent application by was of Notice of Motion in which the Australian Broadcasting Corporation for the Court’s consent under s 11(4)(b) of the Children (Criminal Proceedings) Act 1987 (“the Act’) for the publication of the name of a child who was the offender in criminal proceedings in this court. I made orders after hearing the application but because I had a part heard matter commencing at 10 am the applicant agreed that I should set out my reasons in a judgment which will be emailed to the applicant’s office later today.2. The Director of Public Prosecution was not served with notice of the application. No other person was served. I am satisfied that service is not necessary for the following reasons. Firstly, the criminal proceedings cannot be identified by number or subject matter because, I have been advised from the bar table, the Dubbo Court Registry has refused to provide the file number as this would be a potential contravention of the Act, so the Director of Public Prosecutions would have very little to go one. Secondly, the child (“Craig”) has consented. Thirdly, I am satisfied that s 11 of the Act does not in fact apply to the publication because the text of the publication is couched such broad terms as to fall outside the purpose of s11.3. I should first set out a brief description of the publication and the reasons for urgency. The applicant is participating in “The Message Stick” Film Festival and the films, “When the Natives Get Restless”, a documentary about the lifestyle of teenage Aboriginals in isolated country towns, is to be shown this Sunday. The purpose of the documentary is to identify and analyse the significant social problems these young people face. From the little of the documentary that I have seen, it is a compassionate and insightful documentary of the same kind as that considered by Hulme J in Regina v Jay Hart (Supreme Court of New South Wales, 7 July 2006, unreported).4. The part of the documentary which is the subject of this application shows adolescent boys and girls talking frankly about their experiences with the law. During this exchange, one of the children appears to make an admission about having been in a juvenile centre. The text of the documentary in which the child (whom I shall call “Craig” and who is now 14 years old) is shown apparently acknowledging he has spent time in a juvenile centre is as follows: 
     
      
      Craig: “I’ll never go to jail… me (bread) bad?” 
       
      Girl: “How would you know?” 
       
      Craig: “Coz I know”  
       
      Girl: “No you don’t”  
       
      Girl: “Coz… they’re bad… they don’t know how to stay out of trouble” 
       
      Boy: “They will be down, that’s what they will be” 
       
      Craig: “Not me boy…” 
       
      Boy: “Can’t you be out of juvenile centre you cunt?” 
       
      Craig: “You don’t care, that doesn’t mean I’ll go back to jail my (bread) bad?” 
      
    5. The applicant has made inquiries and ascertained that at an unknown date the child shown apparently admitting that he had in fact spent time in a juvenile detention centre had indeed done so, as a result of a sentence imposed in the District Court at Dubbo. The crime or crimes for which he was convicted are unknown to the applicant because the court staff at Dubbo were not prepared to reveal the charges, or even to give the applicant the file number for the District Court criminal proceedings in which the child was convicted. I do not know if any orders were made during those proceedings for the use of pseudonyms.6. The child has consented to being named and copies of his consent, witnessed by his mother, have been tendered.7. The applicant has responsibilities as a model litigant. It brings a Notice of Motion seeking the following orders: 
     
      
      (a) The Court consents to the publication and broadcasting of the name of the child in connection with these proceedings in the program “When the Natives Get Restless” (“Program”), such consent to extend to any republication or rebroadcast of the Program or any part of it. 
       
       
      (b) Such further or other orders as this Honourable Court thinks fit. 
       
      
    8. Section 11 of the Children (Criminal Proceedings) Act provides: 
     
      
      “(1) The name of any of the following persons must not be published or broadcasted in a way that connects the person with the criminal proceedings concerned: 
       
        
       (a) any person who: 
        
         
        (i) appears as a witness before a court in any criminal proceedings, or to whom any criminal proceedings relate, and 
         
         
        (ii) was a child when the offence to which the proceedings relate was committed, … 
        
       
       
      (1A) The prohibition in subsection (1) applies to the publication or broadcast of the name of a person: 
       
        
       (a) whether the publication or broadcast occurs before or after the proceedings concerned are disposed of, and 
        
        
       (b) even if the person is no longer a child, or is deceased, at the time of the publication or broadcast. 
       
       
      (4) Subsection (1) does not prohibit: 
       
        
       (a) the publication or broadcasting of an official report of the proceedings of a court that includes the name of any person the publication or broadcasting of which would otherwise be prohibited by subsection (1), or 
        
        
       (b) the publication or broadcasting of the name of a person: 
        
         
        (i) in the case of a person who is a child under the age of 16 years at the time of publication or broadcasting – with the consent of the court concerned, or 
         
         
        (ii) in the case of a person who is of or above the age of 16 years at the time of publication or broadcasting – with the consent of the person, or 
        
        
       (c) the publication or broadcasting of the name of a person who has been convicted of a serious indictable offence, if the publication or broadcasting is authorised by a court under section (4B). 
       
       
      (4A) The consent of the court referred to in subsection (4) (b) (i) shall not be given except with the concurrence of the child or (if the child is incapable of giving concurrence) where the court is of the opinion that the pubic interest so requires. 
       
       
      (4B) A court that sentences a person on conviction for a serious children’s indictable offence may, by order made at the time of sentencing, authorise the publication or broadcasting of the name of the person (whether or not the person consents or concurs). 
       
       
      (4C) A court is not to make an order referred to in subsection (4B) unless it is satisfied: 
       
        
       (a) that the making of such an order is in the interests of justice, and 
        
         
        
       (b) that the prejudice to the person arising from the publication or broadcasting of the person’s name in accordance with such an order does not outweigh those interests.”  
       
       
      (4D) The burden of establishing the matters referred to in subsection (4C) (a) and (b) lies on the prosecuting authority. 
       
       
      (4E) A court that makes an order referred to in subsection (4B) must indicate to the person, and make a record of, its reasons for doing so. 
       
       
      (5) For the purposes of this section, a reference to the name of a person includes a reference to any information, picture or other material that identifies the person or is likely to lead to the identification of the person. 
       
       
      (6) For the purposes of this section, a reference to a person who appears as a witness before a court in any criminal proceedings includes a reference to a child who gives evidence in the form of a recording in proceedings in accordance with Part 3 of the  
      Evidence (Children) Act 
       1997. 
       
      
    9. I am informed that the researches of counsel have not revealed any prior authorities that may be of assistance other than Regina v Jay Hart (Hulme J, Supreme Court of NSW, 7 July 2006) and Application by John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd re MSK, MAK, MMK and MRK [2006] NSWCCA 386.10. I should first note the submission that the District Court, where the child was sentenced, is “the court concerned” for the purposes of section 4(b)(i) and that for practical purposes there is no difference between the District Court at Sydney and the District Court at Dubbo. This means that the application is brought in the criminal proceedings in which the child was sentenced at Dubbo District Court. 11. I also note that section 4A envisages that a child under the age of 16 may give concurrence to his or her name being mentioned but then goes on to consider a situation where a child is incapable of giving concurrence, in which case the court must look at whether “the public interest” requires that such an application be brought. Since the child in question has consented, there is no requirement to determine public interest.12. The first issue is whether I can make such an order at all. Section 11(4)(a)(i) sets out a formula for excluding from the prohibition publications made which are a part of official proceedings or with the consent of the person (if the person is over 16) or with the consent of the court concerned. The consent of the court shall not be given under section 11(4A) except, as has occurred here, with the concurrence of the child. However, in Application by John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd re MSK, MAK, MMK and MRK [2006] NSWCCA 386 at [12], the Court of Criminal Appeal held that section 11(4B) cannot be invoked other than during the sentencing process, whether the person is named or not and that the words “by order made at the time of sentencing” were “intractable” (at [12] per Spigelman CJ). Parliament intended to confine applications for an order of this character to the time and to the court which undertook the sentencing task. This section, which intractably forbids later applications, appears to conflict with section 11(4)(1)(i) and (ii), which permit the naming of the child in the circumstances outlined above.13. The applicant relied upon the decision of Hulme J in Regina v Jay Hart, where an order for publication of the names of three deceased children was made although Hulme J does not appear to have been the sentencing judge. This decision was handed down six month before Application by John Fairfax Publications Pty Ltd re MSK, MAK, MMK and MRK. The sections referring to the sentencing judge’s role “whether the person consents or not” in section 11(4B), and the process set out in section 4(b)(i) and (ii) where a child over 16 may consent or the “court concerned” can make an order, are difficult to reconcile.14. However, it is not necessary for me to determine whether an application can be brought once the proceedings have been concluded, because the requirements of section 11(1) have first to be satisfied. The name of the child must not be published or broadcast “in a way that connected the person with the criminal proceedings concerned”. In other words, the publication needs to connect (or identify) the child with the actual criminal proceedings concerned.15. That has not happened here. There is nothing in the documentary that identifies the child with “the criminal proceedings concerned”. No information at all is provided in the documentary about what the criminal proceedings were. All that is shown is that the child appears to have made an admission about spending some time in a juvenile centre. The language of the adolescents’ conversation is so general that not much more can be made out of it than that Craig says he is determined “never to go to jail”. 16. The manner in which section 11 functions is not dissimilar to the functioning of section 121 Family Law Act 1975 (Cth), which prohibits the publication of information about Family Court proceedings. The elements of this section were considered in Markisic v AEA Ethnic Publishers Pty Ltd & Ors [2006] NSWCA 378 and at [179] I note one of the submissions made by the respondent, and apparently accepted by the court, was that the account of the appellant kidnapping his daughters was not an “account of any proceedings” in the Family Court and therefore section 121 had no relevance. 17. The purpose of section 11 is to prevent public identification of a minor which connects that minor with the criminal proceedings concerned. In the present case, not only are the criminal proceedings not identified, but the statements made by Craig are equivocal. There has been no breach of section 11 and accordingly I make the following orders:Orders1. Grant leave to file Notice of Motion in the Registry subject to the registry ascertaining from the Dubbo District Court file number(s) for any criminal proceedings brought against Craig Gillon in that court.2. Dispense with service on the DPP by reason of the consent of the respondent Craig Gillon to publication.3. Notice of Motion dismissed.4. These orders to be entered forthwith. 
   
  
 
 
 
 
 

			
				
			

			











			






			
				DISCLAIMER - Every effort has been made to comply with suppression orders or statutory provisions prohibiting publication that may apply to this judgment or decision. The onus remains on any person using material in the judgment or decision to ensure that the intended use of that material does not breach any such order or provision. Further enquiries may be directed to the Registry of the Court or Tribunal in which it was generated.

title: Breen v Nationwide News Pty Ltd & Ors (No. 2) [2007] NSWDC 233
content:
New South WalesDistrict Court 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
  
   
    
   CITATION: 
   Breen v Nationwide News Pty Ltd & Ors (No. 2) [2007] NSWDC 233 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
    EX TEMPORE JUDGMENT DATE : 
    19 October 2007 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   JURISDICTION: 
   Civil 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   JUDGMENT OF: 
   Gibson DCJ  
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   DECISION: 
   (1) Grant the plaintiff leave to file and serve a further amended statement of claim; (2) The plaintiff pay the costs thrown away by reason of the amendment to the statement of claim; (3) Defendant’s application under the Slip Rule in relation to order 2 of the judgment of 4 October 2007 is dismissed; (4) The defendant is to pay the plaintiff’s costs of the argument today; (5) Orders as per paragraphs 2, 3 and 4 of the short minutes of order. 
   
   
    
    
    
   
  
 
 
  
   
    
   CATCHWORDS: 
   Tort - defamation - imputations - capacity - costs 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   LEGISLATION CITED: 
   Defamation Act 2005 (NSW)Uniform Civil Procedure Rules (NSW), Part 36 r 17 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   CASES CITED: 
   Amalgamated Television Services Pty Limited v Marsden (1998) 43 NSWLR 158Breen v Nationwide News Pty Limited and Ors [2007] NSWDC 192Brimaud v Honeysett Instant Print Pty Ltd (New South Wales Supreme Court, 19 September 1988, unreported)Cretazzo v Lombardi (1975) 16 SASR 1Favell v Queensland Newspapers Pty Limited (2005) 79 ALJR 1716General Steel Industries Inc v Commissioner for Railways (NSW) (1964) 112 CLR 125Griffith v John Fairfax Publications (2004) NSWCA 300Malcolm v Nationwide News Pty Limited [2007] NSWCA 254Manning v Nominal Defendant [2000] NSWCA 80 Sergi v Australian Broadcasting Commission [1983] 2 NSWLR 669  
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   PARTIES: 
   Plaintiff: Peter James BreenFirst Defendant: Nationwide News Pty LtdSecond Defendant: Janet Fife-YeomensThird Defendant: Caroline Overington  
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   FILE NUMBER(S): 
   66 of 2007 
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   COUNSEL:  
   Plaintiff: R PotterDefendants: S Chrysanthou  
   
   
    
    
    
   
   
    
   SOLICITORS:  
   Plaintiff: Turner Freeman LawyersDefendants: Blake Dawson Waldron Lawyers   
   
   
    
    
    
   
  
 
 
  
  
  
  
  
  
 
 
 
  
   
    
   JUDGMENT1. The defendant in these proceedings comes before me today with two applications. The first is to oppose an application by the plaintiff for leave to amend three of the imputations in the statement of claim and to file an amended pleading inserting the word “sexual” before imputations 4(b), 6(b) and 9(b).2. The orders I have already made in this matter are set out in my judgment Breen v Nationwide News Pty Limited & Ors [2007] NSWDC 192. The plaintiff has already agreed that if leave is granted that the plaintiff will pay the costs thrown away by reason of the amendment. 3. The text of the matter complained of is set out in my judgment in Breen v Nationwide News Pty Limited & Ors. The passages the plaintiff relies upon are essentially the whole of the matter complained of, but in particular, the following in relation to each of publications A, B and C.Publication A:4. The plaintiff draws my attention to the headings “MP’s love for vicious killers”, “Sickening bid to free rapists”. The opening paragraphs refer to the plaintiff having:  
     
     “penned a sickening tribute to the killers of Janine Balding in which he talks about his realisation one night in ‘under the stars’ that he loved two of them.” 
    5. In particular, the matter complained of goes on to say that the plaintiff, who is described as a “controversial MP”, describes the vicious killers in his new book as “having rosy cheeks”, “pleasant smiles” or being “hapless”, and goes on to say that the oldest of the three killers is innocent of the murder, adding: 
     
      
     “Mr Breen calls ‘blue eyed’ Jamieson by his nickname Jamo. He bought him a television for his cell... 
      
      
     “Jamieson is gazing out the high barred window behind me, his eyes reflecting blue sky” is how Mr Breen describes one gaol meeting in his bizarre paperback, researched mainly in parliamentary time...  
      
      
     ‘I love Shorty Jamieson and I'm not afraid to say so’.” 
    Publication B:6. The portions relied on in publication B are again the headline and opening words, which include the reference to the book as being “his sick book” in which he said he “loved two of Janine Balding’s killers”, and goes on to say that he had been "forced to quit" the ALP after The Daily Telegraph revealed the “shocking contents” and that the Attorney General’s Office had been asked to step in. Mr Potter draws to my attention to the references at line 37 and line 109 in which the publication asserts that the plaintiff “loves two of the killers of Janine Balding”. Publication C:7. The third matter complained of has Mr Breen quoted as saying he is “sorry if people find this shocking” and there is a reference to acts of cruelty by one of the killers as a child, including animal cruelty, and also a statement that the oldest of the group who has been routinely described in press reports as a “hideous creature” with “ape line features, a flat vacant face, and a strange stunted body” being only 122 centimetres tall with an IQ of 65.The imputations argument8. Each of the three matters complained of sets out the circumstances in which the plaintiff is asserted to have declared his love for the two of the vicious killers of Janine Balding in circumstances where the plaintiff draws to my attention that not only is the plaintiff asserted to have declared his love for another man but it is more than one other man and it is in particular the two vicious killers of Janine Balding which they had been notorious throughout New South Wales, if not Australia, as one of the most dreadful rape and murder cases over the last twenty years at least. 9. Miss Chrysanthou, for the defendants, submits that "love" means sexual conduct and not perverse conduct and that what is asserted here is romantic love, not conduct that is capable of being sexually perverse. 10. Miss Chrysanthou draws to my attention the decision of the Court of Appeal in Malcolm v Nationwide News Pty Limited [2007] NSWCA 254. The circumstances of this case were that Simpson J considered that, when regard was had to the entirety of the news article, it was clear beyond what the Court of Appeal calls in its headnote “reasonable doubt” that what was being reported was a suspicion that the person depicted in the photograph was the person who committed the offence. 11. The Court of Appeal, when allowing an appeal from her Honour’s decision striking out an imputation “the appellant had abducted and indecently assaulted a seven year old boy”, reviewed the law relating to capacity, noting firstly the decision of the Court of Appeal in Griffith v John Fairfax Publications (2004) NSWCA 300 concerning imputations under the 1974 Act, then Favell v Queensland Newspapers Pty Limited (2005) 79 ALJR 1716 concerning the position at common law. The Court then came to a consideration of the tests in Sergi v Australian Broadcasting Commission [1983] 2 NSWLR 669 and in Amalgamated Television Services Pty Limited v Marsden (1998) 43 NSWLR 158. 12. The publication in Malcolm was made on 29 June 2005. The publications that are before me now are 2006 publications. Accordingly these matters fall within the ambit of the Defamation Act 2005 (NSW) which commences in relation to actions after 1 January 2006. 13. Beazley J in Malcolm considered that the test for imputations was as follows: 
     
     “20. Thus in  
     Sergi v Australian Broadcasting Commission 
       
     [1983] 2 NSWLR 669 Glass JA at 674 stated that the question whether the imputation was conveyed should go to the jury unless it was blindingly obvious that no other conclusion was reasonably open. In  
     Amalgamated Television Services v Marsden 
       
     (1998) 43 NSWLR 158 Hunt CJ at CL (Mason P and Handley JA agreeing) stated at 164-165 that if reasonable persons may differ as to the conclusions to be drawn from the matter complained of, the issue as to whether the imputation was in fact conveyed must be left to the jury”. 
    14. Miss Chrysanthou submits to me that this is a break with the use of the General Steel test, a case which has been referred to by Nicholas J in relation to a number of decisions his Honour has handed down on capacity. 15. Prior to the Defamation Act 2005 the General Steel test was not referred to in capacity arguments other than capacity arguments in relation to extrinsic facts, those being matters of pleading. What Miss Chrysanthou submits to me that the Court of Appeal is doing in Malcolm is drawing back from the General Steel test on the basis that it is necessary to establish that it is “reasonable”. In other words, if reasonable persons may differ, in some way this imposes a higher test than the General Steel test. 16. It is my view that the District Court should in the interests of judicial comity follow the decisions of Nicholas J and the Supreme Court. Miss Chrysanthou has told me that there has been a recent case which unfortunately is not available where Nicholas J has resiled from the use of the General Steel test and has preferred to follow Malcolm v Nationwide News Pty Limited. 17. However Mr Potter tells me, and I agree, that I do not need to worry about this apparent conflict as to what the test is, because on any test there is sufficient in each of the matters complained of for him to be able to persuade me that his client should be granted leave to amend to plead these imputations. 18. When one looks at the question of what is a matter for the jury it is hard to think of a better area for jury determination than issues about whether expressing love for two convicted killers is indeed romantic love, or is a perverse sexual attraction. This is a quintessential jury question. A jury can make a decision that is based on community values and their understanding of what the ordinary reasonable reader would make of such an article. Sometimes juries have returned answers of this kind which have surprised lawyers; for example, famously in one case, the jury held that an imputation that the plaintiff, Dr Cairns, felt “a kind of love” for a Miss Morosi was not defamatory. These are matters for which we have juries. This is a quintessential jury question and in my view, whatever the test may be, the loose language of the matter complained of and the certainty that the ordinary reasonable reader would draw inferences and read between the lines mean that there is ample evidence from the text of each of the matters complained of to warrant this amendment.The costs application19. The second application brought by the defendant is in relation to the issue of costs arising from my judgment of [2007] NSWDC 192. This application is brought under the Slip Rule (Uniform Civil Procedure Rules Part 36 r 17), on the basis that I erred in finding that the plaintiff had identified substantial flaws in the defence which necessitated re-pleading (at [68] of my judgment).20. The word “substantial” was not a word of my using, it was a word of Mr Leopold’s adoption, as I note from transcript p 1 line 26 where Mr Leopold said there were “substantial changes” and that he did not seek to press the defence any longer, which of course meant that he was relying on the amended defence that was before me. Miss Chrysanthou tells me that she read [68] of my judgment as meaning that the plaintiff in the course of argument before me identified substantial flaws in the defence that was before me which necessitated re-pleading. But all I was doing was reciting matters of history which are set out more fully in my judgment at [9] where I said this: 
     
      
     “When the matter came before me, the plaintiff provided written submissions identifying a number of errors in the pleading and particularisation of comment. Rather than answer this, the defendant sought leave to amend and provided a draft defence. Some of the proposed amendments appear to be inconsistent with the defence of contextual truth (particularly in regard to imputations 4(b), 6(b), 9(b) and 11(b)) and the document bears the signs of a hastily drafted document. I have taken this into account when formulating my orders and also in relation to costs. In addition, Mr Leopold made some concessions during the argument which necessitated my ordering the transcript to ensure I had recorded them correctly.” 
    21. The defendant complains, with some justification, that they were successful to a large degree, Miss Chrysanthou in fact submitted they were entirely successful in their application before me to oppose the plaintiff’s application to strike out the defence of comment. 22. However, in exercising my discretion as to costs, I heard submissions from the parties and I made an order which took into account the history of the matter rather than separating out the acknowledgment and concessions by the defendant that they would pay the costs thrown away, and I also took into account the lateness with which the amended pleading had been filed and the fact that there were some unspecified number of matters still requiring correction. Miss Chrysanthou says that the amended defence was filed on the date by which submissions are due and that is correct. However, essentially what she objects to is that I took a global approach to costs rather than an issue by issue approach to costs and that is not a matter which, in my view, could fall within the slip rule because it requires the exercise of a discretion. It is not a subject matter about which no real difference of opinion can exist. Essentially what I am being asked to do is to revisit my earlier costs order. 23. Miss Chrysanthou initially sought an order for costs in her clients’ favour. It was drawn to her attention by Mr Potter that when costs were argued before me Mr Leopold did not ask for costs; he asked for no order as to costs or costs in the cause.
